Name: 0b10
Content:
This is the main complex. Cogmind starts from the bottom [[Scrapyard]] level at depth -11. Every level have stairs to an upper level until level -1 where the surface [[Access]] can be found. The levels can also contain other doorways which lead to different branches that eventually connect to the main complex. Read more about all levels at [[Locations]].
[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Complex 0b10[[/Lore]]
Entrances to new levels are implied to be long uneventful corridors where Cogmind loses all pursuers.
0b10 means 2 (0b - binary representation, 10 - 2 in decimal). [[Spoiler]]This means Complex 0b10 is the second complex, 0b1 presumably being first.[[/Spoiler]]

Name: 0b10 Alert Chip
Content: Analyzes ambient [[0b10]] signals to guess the alert level. The best part of this item is the reduction of influence by 20%. This item is obtainable from the exiles.

Content:
Allows entrance into [[Lab]] and [[Redacted]]reveals the hidden intruder detecting lasers.[[/Redacted]]

Name: Achievements
Content:
There are currently 256 achievements in Cogmind, which can be viewed in-game through the Achievements records submenu. They are divided into several categories organized by color, with the appearance of their borders sometimes providing additional information. 81 of the 256 Achievements have hidden descriptions that are only revealed after completing them.

Visually, Achievements are tile-based 5x5 squares. While an Achievement is locked, the inner 3x3 square is made out of question marks. Unlocking an Achievement changes the inner 3x3 square to visually represent the Achievement's requirements/results. The tiles on the border of the 5x5 square almost never change when the Achievement is unlocked. [[Comment]]Those achievements are "Stardust" and "Planet Killer". this is because Wins Achievements' inner art isn't a square but more of a cog, so some of the outer border tiles are part of said art, even if it's just a matching background. This dark green background is the same for all Wins Achievements, except those two. The locked versions, however, still have that dark green background.[[/Comment]]

[[Style Achievements]]|Blue|46|12|-Reaching a high statistic in a specific category

-Visiting/exiting specific areas

Almost all achievements can and have to be completed within a single run, with the exception of "Back For More", "True Cogmind", and all achievements that require reaching/earning 25/50/75/100% of lore collection/gallery collection/achievements.
In addition, some achievements are exclusive to other achievements (for example, all "Specialist" are mutually exclusive to one another), and some are seed-dependent and as a result may not be completable on some seeds (For example, "Exterminator" is not completable on all seeds).

Name: Alert
Content:
Alert is an underlying mechanic throughout the game that describes Cogmind's apparent threat level to [[0b10]]. It only comes into play in 0b10-controlled maps, primarily on main floors like [[Materials]] or [[Factory]] or a few 0b10 branches. It can be increased by many ways, most often by getting spotted or destroying bots or parts of the level. Alert does naturally dissipate over time, although combat-oriented strategies will almost always generate much more alert than the dissipation rate.
Alert is normally hidden throughout the game, although it can be revealed through a few different ways. [[RIF]]-alignment gives a permanent influence number and alert level indicator on the UI at all times. The [[0b10 Alert Chip]] gives the same indication when equipped. Additionally, alert level can be checked by using the [[GameText]]check_alert[[/GameText]] hack when using a [[Datajacks|Datajack]] on an [[Operator]], or by using the [[GameText]]Alert(Check)[[/GameText]] hack at a [[Terminal]].
There are 2 aspects of the Alert level. The first is the "influence" number, which is the numeric representation of alert. This can only be seen when using RIF or the Alert Chip. The other, the alert level, is an approximation of the influence. Low security is the lowest level of alert when the influence number is less than 200 and does not have any additional information. However, alert levels 1 through 4 are all divided into 26 alphabetical subsections. For example, alert level 1 begins at 200 and ends at 399 influence. Checking the alert level while at 200 influence will report "1-A", and checking at 399 will report "1-Z". This can be used to approximate the influence number, although the exact number does not really matter.
[[Heading]]Alert levels[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]Alert level|Minimum Value|Maximum Value||Low Security|0|199||1|200|399||2|400|699||3|700|1199||4|1200|1599||5|1600|No Max[[/Table]]
Alert level controls only a few aspects of the game: [[Assault Squad|Assaults]], [[Patrol Squad|Searches]], and [[High Security]]. Alert level does not increase the number of patrols or guards on the map in any way. Alert below level 2 does not have any impact on the game. At alert level 2/400 influence, Assaults and [[Search Patrol|Search Patrols]] can start being dispatched. From this point onward, alert is a sliding scale. Increased alert will also increase the overall frequency of Assaults and the number of [[C-30 ARC|ARCs]] that will be dispatched as part of an Assault. Alert level 2 typically only sends a single ARC per Assault wave, but higher alert levels can see two or more being sent frequently.
[[High Security]] is the other affect of alert. It is a special alert level that can only be triggered when at level 5 alert when combat hostiles are destroyed. The higher the influence value, the higher the chance of triggering High Security. [[Maximum Security]] has similar effects as High Security, but is not related to alert except that it sets influence to 1600 if it is lower than that.

[[List:Ordered]]Successful hacking increases alert more if the hack is less likely to succeed. Alert does not increase at all from hacks with a success rate of >= 30%.[[/List]]
There are also modifiers that can affect how much alert is gained by a certain percentage. The 0b10 Alert Chip reduces all influence gains by 20%, and the RIF ability Threat Obfuscation reduces all gains by 25%, 40%, or 50% depending on level. All alert reduction is rounded down, and reduction will not take place unless the value is at least 1. For example, gaining 3 influence from destroying a wall on -2 with the Alert Chip equipped results in 0.6 reduction which rounds down to 0. With this 20% reduction, only influence gains of 5 or more will have any reduction applied. On the other hand, having blue or purple allies within a 20-tile radius will increase alert gain from destroying bots. The gain is roughly 12.5% per ally, capping out at an additional 100% alert gain at 8 nearby allies. This effect can be cancelled out by the RIF ability Alert ID Control. In general, be cautious of taking large groups of allies into combat or else alert can quite easily skyrocket.
[[Heading]]Ways to lower alert[[/Heading]]
Lowering alert tends to be quite a bit more difficult than gaining it in the first place for most builds. The best way to dissipate large amounts of alert is to exit the map, as a large percentage of current alert is taken away immediately. Going into [[Caves]] in [[Factory]] branches is even better. By the end of several Caves maps, alert will most likely have dropped down to 0. This alert reduction effect lessens the higher up Cogmind is in the complex, and the amount varies depending on whether Cogmind is exiting into a branch map or a new main depth. Some maps always have fixed alert reduction percentages regardless of floor.

[[Heading:2]]Passive alert reduction[[/Heading]]
The most substantial alert reduction method aside from exiting the map is a passive alert reduction over time. Every 400 turns, influence will decrease by a diminishing value that starts at 200. Each time alert is reduced, the value decreases by 25%.

Name: Alignment
Content:
Alignments are a major part of Cogmind's journey each run. They can provide unique capabilities or trigger certain events, but often lock other pieces of content out as inaccessible. Some factions change large aspects of Cogmind's normal interaction with the game world, while others only trigger a specific event in the game. Some can provide unique [[Wintypes]]. Selecting factions wisely is an important part of a run.
[[Heading]]List of alignments[[/Heading]]
[[List]][[Core Reset Matrix]] (CRM), [[Sigix]] alignment: The CRM is a lategame consumable [[Alien Artifacts|Alien Artifact]] that provides a variety of unique abilities, with the most substantial benefit being the instant detection of all other Alien Artifacts upon consumption or entering a new map. The major downside is a memory wipe that removes most of Cogmind's knowledge. Consuming it also angers a few other factions and locks out certain events.|[[Farcom]], [[Exiles (Group)|Exiles]] alignment: An early game alignment that provides a permanent 18-tile radius combat bot sensor in all [[0b10]]-controlled floors as well as 1 type of unique Exile prototype. Its major downsides are locking out Imprint and a harsh penalty when entering [[Research]] branches [[Testing]], [[Quarantine]], and [[Section 7]].|[[Imprint]], [[Zion]] alignment: A midgame alignment that dramatically changes [[Terminal]] hacking. All standard Terminal hacks are removed and replaced with special random Zion ally summons and intel. Imprint is a powerful but tricky alignment to use due to the loss of standard Terminal hacking. Imprinting also locks Cogmind out of gaining the aid of several other Derelict factions.|[[Redacted]][[MAIN.C]] surrender - 0b10 alignment: This lategame alignment only becomes available in [[Command]] after defeating the [[MAIN.C (Shell)|MAIN.C Shell]] and enables a particular win, w8 by fighting off waves of [[Enhanced Q-Series]]. Surrendering to MAIN.C locks Cogmind out of several ending types, as well as the ability to enter [[Access_0]].[[/Redacted]]|[[Relay Interface Framework]] (RIF), 0b10 alignment: An alignment available as early as [[Materials]], RIF allows for much greater control of 0b10 complex bots through the use of special hacks via [[Relay Couplers]]. RIF also provides many unique abilities that make traversing the complex safer or easier. The major downside of RIF is that several [[Derelict]] factions will be unable to identify Cogmind as friendly and will instead turn hostile.|[[Revision 17 (Alignment)|Revision 17 Alignment]]: [[Revision 17]] is a quite unique Derelict that can be rescued in [[Cetus]]. Revision 17's role is not a large one, but its -3 Research invasion can stir up some trouble and hopefully provide some aid in Research.|[[Redacted]][[Sigix Exoskeleton]], Sigix alignment: The Sigix Exoskeleton is an immensely powerful and gamechanging build type available late in the game in Section 7. It provides Cogmind with lots of firepower, a massive amount of map intel, and fast and high integrity and coverage exoskeleton part. The downsides to the Exoskeleton are reduced slot count (down to 1-3-3-2 initially), a decently low maximum support, and the full weight of 0b10's [[Maximum Security]] sent after Cogmind whenever spotted. This item is very powerful, but drastically changes gameplay for the rest of the run compared to most other alignments.[[/Redacted]]|[[UFD|United Federation of Derelicts]] alignment: The UFD is a Derelict group whose home is in the 0b1 Old Recycling map [[Scraptown]]. Their major benefits include some unique parts available on the map and their ability to summon [[Scrapoid|Scrapoids]] from [[Recycling Machine|Recycling Machines]].|[[Warlord (Alignment)|Warlord Alignment]]: [[Warlord]] is a unique and much beloved Derelict that wages war on 0b10 whose help can be obtained in the midgame. His -2 Research assault is similar to Revision 17's but on a much grander scale. Lots of loot can be found wherever Warlord goes. He can also make an appearance in the [[Redacted]][[Command]] cave seals[[/Redacted]], which can even lead to a unique wintype. The [[Encrypted Comm Array]] also falls under this alignment and turns destruction of 0b10 [[Garrison|Garrisons]] and [[DSF|DSFs]] into more powerful Warlord forces.|[[Zhirov (Alignment)|Zhirov Alignment]]: [[Zhirov]] is another unique Derelict who can provide a big help in the lategame. Grabbing the [[SGEMP Prototype]] in Testing provides a few temporary allies (including Zhirov himself) and full map intel of [[Access]], a notoriously difficult map. His quest can continue on in [[Redacted]]Command, where his Modified SGEMP can disable the whole map's worth of 0b10 bots when the MAIN.C Shell is defeated.[[/Redacted]][[/List]]

Name: Assault Squad
Content:
Assault squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that are sent after Cogmind as a result of having too high [[Alert]]. Assaults are sent directly to Cogmind's position with [[Perfect Tracking]] and cannot be easily shaken. They consist of a single [[C-30 ARC]] typically containing 5 bots inside. If Cogmind has 3 or more allies, up to 2 additional bots may be sent to escort the ARC as additional firepower. Assault squads can be both Enumerated and Recalled at [[Terminal|Terminals]].
An alert indicates whenever an Assault squad is dispatched. Additionally, the log will display a message like [[GameText]]ALERT: Significant disruption in zone 9B, assault force dispatched[[/GameText]]. If more than one ARC was sent, the message will instead indicate [[GameText]]multiple assault carriers dispatched[[/GameText]].
[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]WAR.Sys Records|Assault Squad[[/Lore]]
[[Heading]]Frequency and Number[[/Heading]]
Assaults may be dispatched regularly as long as Cogmind is at least Alert level 2 or 400 influence, although at lower Alert levels Assaults are rare. At Alert levels well above 1000, Assaults may be sent out at nearly opportunity. A higher Alert level also increases the chances of multiple ARCs being dispatched. In [[Materials]], Assaults can be dispatched every 400 turns on -9 and -8. In [[Factory]] and above, this changes to be every 250 turns. If an Assault would be dispatched at the same time an [[Extermination Squad]] would be dispatched, the Assault is delayed by 50 turns. Most assault waves consists of 1-2 ARCs, but at Alert levels in excess of 5X/1600 influence, 3 or even more ARCs can be sent.
[[Heading:2]]During [[High Security|High]] or [[Maximum Security]][[/Heading]]
The frequency, number, and contents of ARCs changes. Assault forces with stronger compositions than usual may be dispatched in these conditions, although these ARCs only have 4 bots inside rather than the typical 5. 4 ARCs will be dispatched 100 turns into High Security and after another 100 turns. After that, 2 more ARCs will be added to each wave, but 50 more turns will be added in between the dispatch of each wave. The sizes of the Assault waves will also start to increase each wave, and the duration between each wave will increase. Maximum Security is similar, but with 6 ARCs to start the first 2 waves. The 2nd wave of Assaults in High Security and all subsequent waves, and all waves of Maximum Security may contain stronger than usual bots in them.
[[Heading]]Assault Contents[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Assault Contents.png|Example contents of an Assault squad ARC[[/Image]]
Assault contents can vary by depth, but their makeups are always similar. Assaults will always contain 4 combat bots and 1 support-type bot. The combat bots may become stronger under heavy assault conditions, but the possible support bots are always the same.

The Data Miner can redirect Assaults if his help is obtained by visiting his [[Data Miner (Location)|hideout]]. If redirected, Assaults will roam around a random area of the map rather than head directly to Cogmind's location. The Data Miner has a 50% chance to direct each ARC as part of an Assault about 15 turns after each Assault is dispatched, if Cogmind is determined as "needing assistance". Redirection can only occur when High/Maximum Security is not active. If a redirect happens, the alert [[GameText]]Higher priority target acquired, redirecting assault.[[/GameText]] will be displayed. If an Assault is not redirected, there is a further 50% chance that the contents may be redirected after the ARC opens up. This can happen within 30 turns of the ARC opening. This effect will only redirect the squad leader, and the squad leader will only leave if currently unable to see Cogmind. All the remaining squad bots will continue to follow Cogmind. The true practical effect here is that if the squad forgets where Cogmind is, they will patrol around the redirected location rather than the location that the ARC opened.[[/Spoiler]]

Name: Cargo Convoy
Content:
[[Image]]Cargo Convoy.png|Intact cargo convoy[[/Image]]
[[Image]]Cargo Convoy Deployed.png|A cargo convoy with ARCs deployed[[/Image]]
Cargo convoys are a special form of [[Transport Squad|transport squads]] that can be found from -7 to -2 on main [[Factory]] and [[Research]] floors. They consist of a single [[A-27 Freighter]], a [[Protector]], and two [[C-30 ARC|C-30 ARCs]] full of 4 combat bots and an extra utility bot, similar to strong [[Assault Squad|assaults]]. The parts contained within a Freighter are all [[Prototype Part|prototype]] or [[Authchips]], never faulty, and can be up to 3 ratings out of depth. For example, on -7, Haulers can contain up to rating 4 prototype parts. A cargo convoy Freighter can carry rating 5-7 prototype parts.
Cargo convoys are always preceded by 3-5 [[Swarmer|Swarmers]] that scout out the path of the convoy before it appears. The alert [[GameText]]Cargo convoy en route, clear transfer corridor.[[/GameText]] will indicate when this is happening. A few turns later, the Freighter and guards will appear and take the same route.
Cargo convoys will always appear at a 0b10 controlled exit and head to a [[Garrison (Machine)|Garrison]]. Typically the Freighter leads the way and stays ahead of the Protector and ARCs, which normally trail a few tiles behind. A [[Transport Network Coupler]] or [[Modified TNC]] will reveal the planned path of the Freighter. The Modified TNC will also show the contents of the Freighter. The Manifests hack will also show all the parts contained by the Freighter.
[[Heading]]Unique parts[[/Heading]]
There are 2 fully unique Cargo Convoy drops as well as one semi-unique drop:
[[List]][[Active Cooling Armor]]: Only obtainable from Cargo Convoy|[[Exp. Thermic Cannon]]: Only obtainable from Cargo Convoy|[[PL-3XN's Ring of Power]]: Only obtainable from one Cargo Convoy per run. Can be found in other locations.[[/List]]
[[Heading]]Attack response[[/Heading]]
If a cargo convoy is attacked, a message will indicate this, as well as an alert: [[GameText]]ALERT: Cargo convoy interrupted, initiating access lockdown.[[/GameText]] 100 turns after this, a [[Heavy]] will spawn at an 0b10 controlled exit or Garrison every 100 turns until all exits are guarded by a Heavy. Heavies may head toward a far away [[Caves]] exit in order to guard it. The Freighter will begin running away in a random direction when attacked. If it is not destroyed, it will head toward another nearby 0b10 controlled exit.
[[Heading]][[Derelict]] attack[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Cargo Convoy Attack.png|Derelicts from a Garrison ready to assault a convoy[[/Image]]
There is a chance that Derelicts will decide to attack a cargo convoy. The chance is higher at lower depths. If they attack, they will appropriate a Garrison machine, rig some [[Dirty Bomb Trap|Dirty Bomb Traps]], and attack the convoy guards. If they are successful, they will retreat and leave the loot available for Cogmind. This may happen even if Cogmind is nowhere near the convoy. It may be a good idea to track the Freighter position in case this happens, even if not planning to attack the convoy directly, since this can often result in lots of powerful free loot. If Cogmind is not close enough to grab the loot, [[Recycler|Recyclers]] may have carried it off to a nearby [[Recycling Machine]]. Make sure to check these if the Freighter's stash can't be found nearby.

Name: Cave-ins
Content:
Cave-ins are a [[Game Mechanics|Game Mechanic]] where dug-out tiles will collapse and instantly deal a large amount of Impact damage to anything on the tile. It is safe to dig up to 3 tiles safely in some circumstances, but long distance digging is always unsafe.
[[Heading]]Causes of cave-ins[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Destabilized Tiles.png|Destabilized tiles are bright red as shown by a Structural Scanner[[/Image]]
[[Heading:2]]Destabilization[[/Heading]]
Destabilized tiles are tiles that will always collapse if given enough time. They may collapse instantly or they may last a hundred turns or more. Destabilized tiles can be viewed with a [[Structural Scanner]]. A tile can become destabilized in two ways:
[[List]]Explosive damage - Explosive damage (namely [[Launchers]]) will cause a tile to destabilized.|Attacking from a dug out tile - If Cogmind or any other bot fires a weapon inside of a dug out tile, the tile will destabilize. This tile may collapse instantly before Cogmind gets a chance to move, so digging from inside these tiles is never completely safe.[[/List]]
[[Heading:2]]Dug-out tile traversal[[/Heading]]
It is safe to travel through dug out tiles (that are not destabilized) for up to 3 tiles, but they have to be wall-earth-wall or wall-wall-wall tiles. For a longer dig, wall-earth-earth is not safe. Each tile traversed past that safe limit will risk an instant cave-in.
[[Heading]]Example digs[[/Heading]]
[[Gallery]]Wall Earth Wall Dig.png|Safe 3 tile dig with a ranged weapon: Wall-earth-wall|Wall Dig.png|Safe 1 tile dig with a melee weapon: Wall only|Wall Wall Dig.png|UNSAFE 2 tile dig: Digging within a dug out tile is unsafe|Wall Earth Earth Wall Dig.png|UNSAFE 4 tile dig: Wall-earth is safe, second half earth-wall is unsafe[[/Gallery]]
[[Heading]]Avoiding cave-ins[[/Heading]]
Here are some strategies to avoid cave-ins
[[List]]Don't use melee to dig more than 1 tile - Melee weapons need to be adjacent to the next tile to dig out. This means Cogmind will have to be in a dug out tile to dig two consecutive tiles which allows a chance for an immediate destabilization cave-in.|Don't use Explosive Launchers to dig - While Launchers can dig out a lot of tiles at once, those tiles have a chance to collapse as Cogmind walks through. Note: it is safe to do this with a Structural Scanner equipped, as destabilized tiles will be visible and are avoidable.|Use Thermal or Kinetic cannons - These cannons have a high base damage that is typically strong enough to dig through most non-reinforced walls. It is safe to dig a 3 tile path ahead of time and then walk through at no risk of cave-in.|Be wary of [[U-05 Engineer|Engineers]] - Engineers may seal off your path and leave you stuck in the wall, forced to dig again to escape and risk immediate cave-in.[[/List]]

Name: Challenges Achievements
Content:
Challenges [[Achievements]] are earned by completing certain challenging feats, demonstrating the player's large experience with the game. Only some of them are likely to be obtained naturally by players not actively trying to earn them. 2 of the 27 Challenges Achievements have hidden descriptions that are only revealed after completing them. The borders of Challenges Achievements tend to indicate their general difficulty as a Challenges Achievement[[Comment]]Rincewind being the biggest exception. Why is that one considered "easy"? It's basically the most difficult one in here.[[/Comment]], with more "intense" borders meaning higher difficulty.

[[Comment]]This warning is supposed to be there for all articles about achievement types, including those that do not have any Redacted-level spoilers.[[/Comment]]
(The visibility for the explanations, strategies and descriptions of hidden achievements is set to at least "Spoilers", and may be set to "Redacted" for achievements where that would be relevant. Remember to change your spoilers settings to "None" if you do not wish to see the explanations, strategies and descriptions of hidden achievements you have not yet obtained!)

Warning: The writer of this article has not yet earned the "Full Golem" Achievement, and as such its description in this page is a (likely accurate) guess instead of being the official description.

[[Comment]]Important note : A lot of Challenges Achievements' descriptions mention by name some spoiler-tier stuff, such as the Cetus Guards or Transdimensional Reconstructors.
Normally, these names would be contained within a Link tag.
However, because those Achievements' descriptions are not hidden by the game (the descriptions themselves aren't spoiler-tier), these names should not be contained within a Link tag, because that would cause them to appear spoilered to anyone with a spoiler setting of "None".[[/Comment]]

[[Heading]]Challenge difficulty level 1[[/Heading]]
[[List]]Exterminator: Destroy 15 [[Assembled]] in the [[Mines]].
Strategy: This Achievement is seed-dependent, and may be impossible on some seeds. When attempting to get this Achievement on a random seed, visit the Mines and bring at least one [[Launchers|launcher]]. If an Assembled infestation occurs, try to find and reach the source as quickly as possible, to be able to blow up the Assembled while they are still in a somewhat large group. Having a [[Seismic Detector]] can help locate the Assembled faster.
|Killing Spree: Achieve a kill streak of 20 hostiles.
|Preemptive Strike: Destroy a visible [[C-30 ARC|ARC]] before it deploys.
|Left-hand Path: Destroy all Cetus Guards without any help from allies.
|Below: Visit and survive 2 [[Wastes|Waste]] areas.

|Rincewind: Use at least 10 Transdimensional Reconstructors (any variant).
|Leap Before You Look: Enter 10 unidentified exits.
Strategy: It is possible to deduce the identity of exits without actually "identifying" the exit, through various means. For example, successfully hacking branch exits would cause all remaining unidentified exits to be main exits, and vice-versa. It is also possible to identify some exits by where they are or what's around them, such as [[Mines]] exits, which are always surrounded by mining equipment. This is especially true in branches, where all exits are distinguishable from each other. This can allow entering exits the game considers "unidentified", while actually knowing where they lead, making this Achievement much easier. If you have a [[Signal Interpreters|Signal Interpreter]] attached, remember to deactivate it before approaching any exits you would want to take while unidentified, as it would automatically identify them.[[/List]]

Name: Chronowheel
Content:
The effect of the Chronowheel allows Cogmind to rewind time as a one time save/load effect. Attaching saves, and after 30 turns (if not destroyed/removed) the load will occur.
[[Heading]]Timeline of Effects[[/Heading]]
[[List]]1 - [[GameText]]Spacetime feels off.[[/GameText]] log message. Random part art, map sections, and lore text will briefly flash on screen. The frequency of these effects increases as time goes on.|20 - [[GameText]]Chronowheel is disintegrating...[[/GameText]] log|28 - [[GameText]]Spacetime is rapidly distorting...[[/GameText]] log|29 - [[GameText]]Spacetime reconverges on this point.[[/GameText]] log. Turn before attaching the Chronowheel is loaded, Chronowheel is gone.|When ripping the Chronowheel off instead - [[GameText]]Spacetime feels normal again.[[/GameText]] log[[/List]]
Some good uses of the Chronowheel include:
[[List]]Determining what map an exit goes to (a very expensive one time [[Signal Interpreter]], not really recommended)|Scouting out a new map or running through a dangerous area (only really viable if fast)|Getting multiple attempts at killing the [[Data Miner]]|Using the [[Data Conduit]] and finding the locations of all locations in the game without the negative side effects|Getting the chance to reroll a [[RIF]] ability from a RIF Installer|Attaching unknown [[Alien Artifacts]] or [[Prototype Part|Prototype Parts]] without downsides. This is especially useful if used with a [[Core Reset Matrix]], since it will show where all other Alien Artifacts are on the current map.|Completing [[Zhirov|Zhirov's]] [[SGEMP Prototype]] quest and obtaining the [[Access]] map intel without actually getting Zhirov to spawn in Access.[[/List]]
[[Heading:2]]Secret second effect[[/Heading]]
[[Spoiler]]The Chronowheel also has a hidden secondary effect when paired with the [[Subatomic Replicator]]. First, the warning [[GameText]]Chronowheel temporarily destabilized by failed replication attempt, a second attempt will likely cause a devastating explosion.[[/GameText]] will appear in the log. A second attempt will give the message [[GameText]]Local interference in replication process, triggered subspace vortex.[[/GameText]] A 20 tile radius explosion will then occur at the point of replication, dealing 1000 vortex damage in 10 damage chunks with 0 falloff.[[/Spoiler]]

Name: Companion Sword
Content:
The Companion Sword is a unique talking melee weapon that can only appear in [[Scraptown]]. It is contained in a room called The Sword, locked for the protection of [[Derelict|Derelicts]], none of whom have survived using the Companion Sword for long. The Companion Sword is quite talkative and will often comment about the state of the run, take pleasure in destroying things, and complain if it is detached or is not the only weapon attached. The Companion Sword has a variety of special effects that are not described by the in-game effect.
[[Heading]]Special Effects[[/Heading]]

The log message [[GameText]]Companion Sword surprise attacks [target].[[/GameText]] will appear when this happens.|Uncommon||Core Loss|The Companion Sword deals between 5-10 core damage directly to Cogmind's core on a normal attack. Can't be reduced by [[Core Shieldings]] or [[Defensive Utilities]]. Only happens when Cogmind attacks something with the Companion Sword.|Uncommon||Bot Disruption|A bot is instantly disrupted on a normal attack. Name: Core Reset Matrix
Content:
The Core Reset Matrix, or CRM, is a consumable [[Alien Artifacts]] that provides one of the [[Alignment|alignment]] options in the game. It provides a combination of helpful and unhelpful effects, and as such should often not be used in every game unlike other consumable items.
[[Heading]]Effects[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:3]]Alien Alliance[[/Heading]]
[[Assembled]] and [[Golem|Golems]] will turn from hostile to purple uncontrollable allies. Additionally, if [[Imprint|Imprinted]], [[Redacted]][[Z-Light|Z-Lights]], [[Z-Heavy|Z-Heavies]], and [[Experimental|Experimentals]] summoned from [[Command]] cave seals will turn from purple into blue controllable allies.[[/Redacted]]
[[Heading:3]]Alien Artifact Detection[[/Heading]]
After consuming the CRM and when entering a new map, the locations and types of all Alien Artifacts are revealed on the map. The part IDs of all Alien Artifacts are also granted to Cogmind.
[[Heading:3]]Alien Language Understanding[[/Heading]]
Cogmind will be able to understand the speech of the [[Sigix Containment Pod]] when rescued.
[[Redacted]][[Heading:3]]Cave Seal Allies[[/Heading]]
If a Command cave seal is opened and Cogmind is not Imprinted or allied with [[Warlord]], cave seals will initially contain 1 Golem and 10-13 Assembled.[[/Redacted]]
[[Heading:3]][[Corruption]] Cleanse[[/Heading]]
Corruption is reset to 0%.
[[Heading:3]]Hypermatrix Pings[[/Heading]]
When Cogmind's core reaches below 33%, Cogmind will emit a hypermatrix ping and 6-8 Assembled will spawn next to Cogmind. This only happens on main [[0b10]] floors and in [[Command]]. After this, Cogmind will be able to detect further hypermatrix pings at a range of 18 tiles of other groups of assembled. Coming within a few tiles of these pings with visual contact will cause a further 6-8 Assembled to pop out.
[[Heading:3]]Memory Reset[[/Heading]]
Cogmind loses all map data, part IDs, [[Robot Analysis|Analyses]], [[Schematic|Schematics]], [[Data Conduit|Data Conduit intel]], [[RIF]] alliance, [[A7 Data Core|A7 Data Core intel]], and any manual [[Terminal]] or robot hacks. Notably, Cogmind will not lose [[Farcom]] or Imprint.
[[Heading:3]]Non-Alien Hostilities[[/Heading]]
Certain groups will no longer trust Cogmind as a result of using a CRM. If [[Zhirov]] shows up in [[Access]] as a result of completing the [[SGEMP Prototype]] quest, he and his allies will immediately turn hostile to Cogmind. [[Redacted]]The surrender option is no is no longer offered by [[MAIN.C]], causing the W8 [[Wintypes|Wintype]] to be unobtainable.[[/Redacted]]
[[Redacted]][[Heading:3]][[Sigix Exoskeleton]] Control[[/Heading]]
Cogmind is able to pilot the Exoskeleton located in [[Section 7]].[[/Redacted]]
[[Heading:3]]Unique Wintype[[/Heading]]
Taking a [[Surface]] exit after using a CRM awards the W2 wintype.
[[Heading]]Where to find[[/Heading]]
As an Alien Artifact, the CRM is only found in a few specific places:
[[Gallery]][[Redacted]]Lab CRM.png[[/Redacted]]|[[Redacted]][[Lab]], guaranteed spawn every game[[/Redacted]]|Quarantine CRM.png|[[Quarantine]], almost every game in unique machinery|[[Redacted]]Section 7 CRM.png[[/Redacted]]|[[Redacted]]Found in Section 7 unguarded Alien Artifact Suspension Chambers, random chance[[/Redacted]]|[[Redacted]]Section 7 CRM Cache.png[[/Redacted]]|[[Redacted]]1-3 can be found in the Section 7 LRC cache, random chance[[/Redacted]][[/Gallery]]

Name: Coupling Squad
Content:
[[Image]]Coupling Squad.png|A Programmer installing Relay Couplers into a Garrison[[/Image]]
Coupling squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that are sent to restock [[Garrison (Machine)|Garrison Machines]] with [[Relay Couplers]]. They can appear on any 0b10 floor that contains a Garrison as well as on the inside of [[Garrison|Garrisons]]. They consist of a single [[Programmer]] carrying 3-4 Relay Couplers. The Programmer is 1 tier above typical Programmers for the depth. For example, a typical -7 Programmer is a [[P-60 Hacker]], but a coupling squad will instead be a [[P-70 Sage]].
Coupling squads are dispatched if a Garrison has no Relay Couplers in its builtin inventory. Garrison machines usually contain 3-4 Couplers at all times, but sometimes one will be present on initial map entry with none. Full Garrisons will also lose their inventory over time and become empty. In either case, a Programmer will eventually be called to that Garrison to restock the Couplers. When a coupling squad Programmer reaches its target Garrison, a message like [[GameText]]P-70 Sage installs Relay Coupler [Grunt] into garrison access.[[/GameText]] will appear in the log. After all the couplers are installed, the Programmer will exit through the Garrison.
[[Heading]]Intentional dispatching[[/Heading]]
Coupling squads can also dispatched if Cogmind uses the [[Spoiler]]Trojan(Restock)[[/Spoiler]] hack. If this is done, log text similar to [[GameText]]ALERT: Unscheduled coupler replacement inbound for Garrison vPm.7n.[[/GameText]] will appear after a few turns. A similar restock effect will occur if Cogmind uses the [[Spoiler]]Force(Eject)[[/Spoiler]] hack.

Demolisher squads will never exit the map under normal circumstances after being dispatched.
An alert will indicate whenever a Demolisher squad is dispatched. Name: Encrypted Comm Array
Content:
The Encrypted Comm Array, or ECA, is a [[Warlord]]-aligned item that enables summoning various groups of [[Derelict]] allies on main [[0b10]] floors. It can be obtained by performing any of the actions that increase the ECA force multiplier listed below. After this, a Derelict will appear in the next [[Caves]] map and deliver the Array, give some more details on its usage, and reveal the depth of [[Warlord (Location)]]. The ECA cannot be used if Cogmind has been [[Imprint|Imprinted]] or made use of a [[RIF|RIF installer]], as these alignments are mutually exclusive with Warlord.
[[Heading]]Summoning squads[[/Heading]]
Equipping the ECA on any main 0b10 floor will reveal up to 8 squads available for summoning. Each time a squad is summoned, the force multiplier is decreased by 0.01. Moving over one of the squad indicators on the map will summon several white colored [[Alert]]-free allies that will follow Cogmind around the map, but will not follow to any other maps. These bots also do not gain trap location knowledge from Cogmind like purple or blue allies, so they may move over known traps. The squads do not get stronger as depth increases, so they have less utility in late [[Factory]] and [[Research]] depths. All squads have a chance of containing a [[Surgeon]] that will repair any allied bots as well as Cogmind. The available squads are:
[[List]]Chimera Squad: [[Mutant|Mutants]]|Dakka Squad: [[Wasp|Wasps]]|Muscle Squad: [[Butcher|Butchers]] and [[Savage|Savages]]|Geek Squad: [[Wizard|Wizards]]|Ghost Squad: [[Infiltrator|Infiltrators]]|Infantry Squad: [[Thug|Thugs]]|Pyro Squad: [[Fireman|Firemen]]|Ranger Squad: [[Guerrilla|Guerrillas]][[/List]]
If Cogmind meets Warlord at his base, the squad summoning and force multiplier reporting mechanics stop functioning, and there is no point to hold onto the ECA any longer.
[[Heading]]Force multiplier[[/Heading]]
The ECA brings an additional mechanic to Warlord alignment called the force multiplier. This value is reported every time Cogmind enters a new main 0b10 depth. The force multiplier affects several things:
[[List]]The total number of squads available to summon per map. This starts at 0 squads at a 1.00 force multiplier and caps at 8 at 1.08.|Special guard squads in the -2 [[Research]] Warlord assault event. Based on the performance tier, more bots and stronger squads can be summoned to aid Cogmind during the assault.|-1 [[Access]] spillover forces: In Access, additional Warlord forces will appear at the entrance to the map. More squads will appear with a higher force multiplier.|[[Redacted]]The [[Command]] seals will summon more and stronger bots based on the overall force multiplier.[[/Redacted]][[/List]]
The force multiplier tiers are as follows:
[[List]]D: 1.00 - 1.09|C: 1.10 - 1.19|B: 1.20 - 1.29|A: 1.30 - 1.39|S: 1.40+[[/List]]
The following are the ways that the force multiplier can be modified:
[[Table]]Method|Effect||Sterilizing a DSF|+ 0.10||Garrison interior compromised (once per Garrison)|+ 0.02||Destroying a RIF installer|+ 0.02||Destroying a Garrison Relay|+ 0.01||Destroying a Phase Generator|+ 0.01||Summoning an ECA squad|- 0.01||Ascending a depth|- 0.01[[/Table]]
[[Heading]]Additional abilities[[/Heading]]
The ECA has a unique ability that interacts with [[Heavy]]-summoned [[Reinforcement Squad|Reinforcement Squads]]. Occasionally, [[Specialist|Specialists]] summoned by the Heavy will reveal themselves to be [[Infiltrator|Infiltrators]] in disguise and turn friendly to Cogmind.
[[Heading]]Post-Warlord RIF[[/Heading]]
It is possible to install RIF after meeting Warlord. Warlord and his forces will not turn against Cogmind at this point, as they can only detect RIF inside of the Warlord base. However, doing so will lose some of the benefits. The -2 special guards will not appear based on the force multiplier. [[Redacted]]Additionally, fewer squads will be dispatched to follow Cogmind around from the Command seals. However, the seals will still have a higher number and more powerful bots based on the force multiplier as usual.[[/Redacted]]

Events [[Achievements]] are earned by witnessing or triggering certain events. Most of them will simply eventually be obtained by players as they explore and understand more of the game world and its depths. 40 of the 41 Events Achievements have hidden descriptions that are only revealed after completing them. The borders of Events Achievement have 0-2 squares in their corners, with more squares usually meaning a more important event.

[[Comment]]This warning is supposed to be there for all articles about achievement types, regardless of whether there are any Redacted-level spoilers, because saying there are no Redacted-level spoilers is itself a spoiler.[[/Comment]]
(The visibility for the explanations, strategies and descriptions of hidden achievements is set to at least "Spoilers", and may be set to "Redacted" for achievements where that would be relevant. Remember to change your spoilers settings to "None" if you do not wish to see the explanations, strategies and descriptions of hidden achievements you have not yet obtained!)

Name: Extermination Squad
Content:
[[Image]]Extermination Squad.png|An Extermination Squad hunting down Cogmind[[/Image]]
Extermination squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that are sent after Cogmind periodically in [[Factory]] (-7) and beyond. Exterminations are sent directly to Cogmind with [[Perfect Tracking]] and cannot easily be shaken. Extermination squads typically consist of 1-3 [[Programmer|Programmers]] based on the floor: 1 [[P-60 Hacker]] on -7 and -6, 1 or 2 [[P-70 Sage|P-70 Sages]] on -5 and -4, and 2 or 3 [[P-80 Master|P-80 Masters]] on -3 to -1. Extermination squads can be both Enumerated and Recalled at [[Terminal|Terminals]].
An alert will indicate whenever an an Extermination squad is dispatched. Additionally, the log will display a message like [[GameText]]ALERT: Rogue bot located, Programmers report to Factory Zone 5B.[[/GameText]]
[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]WAR.Sys Records|Extermination Squad[[/Lore]]
[[Heading]]Frequency[[/Heading]]
Extermination squads have a chance of being dispatched by every 250 turns when on most 0b10 maps. The higher the depth, the higher the chance that an Extermination will be sent. If Exterminations fail to be sent 3 times in a row, one will be sent after 1/3 of the average check time. For example, if no Extermination squad is sent for 750 turns, one will be sent in 1/3 of 250 turns, which is 84 turns, or 834 turns total. This means that there are 4 possible combinations of delay between Extermination squads.
The spawn timer can be delayed with [[Spoiler]]the [[RIF]] ability Zone Cloak[[/Spoiler]] or by sealing [[Garrison (Machine)|Garrison Machines]]. Both of these methods stack, and each provides +75 turns to each possible Extermination squad spawn. For example, closing 2 Garrisons while having [[Spoiler]]Zone Cloak 1[[/Spoiler]] will add 225 turns to the 250 turn timer, increasing it up to 475 turns.
The following table showcases possible time periods in between Extermination squads.
[[Table]]# delay sources (e.g. sealed Garrisons)|1st spawn chance|2nd|3rd|Latest possible||0|250|500|750|834||1|325|650|975|1084||2|400|800|1200|1334||3|475|950|1425|1584||4|550|1100|1650|1837[[/Table]]
[[Spoiler]][[Heading]][[Q-Series]][[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Q-Series.png|2 Q-Series coming for Cogmind[[/Image]]
It is possible for Extermination Programmers to be replaced by 1-2 Q-Series instead. This can occur randomly if Cogmind gets scanned by a [[Researcher]] in [[Testing]] or [[Quarantine]]. These Q-Series have customized and randomized loadouts, but will behave in the same way as regular Extermination squads do. This includes heading straight for Cogmind with perfect tracking, and the ability to be recalled at Terminals.[[/Spoiler]]

Name: Fabricator
Content:
Fabricators construct parts and robots based on schematics. [[Schematic|Schematics]] can be acquired by using [[Scanalyzer|Scanalyzers]] or hacking [[Terminal|Terminals]] (see your status page for access to a list of schematics currently in your possession), then loaded into a fabricator which will report the resources it requires to complete construction. Starting another build on a busy fabricator will cancel the current construction. Loading a new schematic and printing it will summon an [[Investigation Squad]], unless you have the appropriate [[Authchips|Authchip]]. [[Image]]../game_sprites/Fabricator.png|Friend Creator[[/Image]]

Building bots will build multiple.

Higher security fabricators are capable of much faster construction.

[[GameText]]>Analysis(G-11 Fodder)[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]The first of the G-series grunts, this model is no longer in production and the relevant schematics will be moved to the Archives.  The G-11 was intended to be fast and cheap to produce and deploy as a deterrent for unarmed Derelicts.  As a result it has a low-integrity core, low-coverage legs and its weapon is a repurposed low-power fabricator laser.  Existing units still number in the hundreds and are being either scrapped or deployed to the caves where they are sometimes useful as diversions.  Many Derelicts still rely on obsolete signal interpreters or seismic detectors, so they are unable to tell the difference between these bots and more capable models.[[/GameText]]

[[GameText]]>Analysis(S-02 Bug)[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]One of my first robot designs was a small hexapod walker made in mass quantities to spread out and survey the surface.  When I began producing combat bots, I revisited this design and added an assault rifle and light armor.  The Bug's armored shell employs adaptive camouflage while the robot is dormant, enabling it to hide from distant hostiles until it wakes up.  The shell also compensates for the core's inherent weakness to explosive damage.  Bug squads were commonly used as patrols or stationed to guard an open area, but flying swarmers and sentries have replaced them in these roles.  All remaining units have been recalled to garrisons to supplement security positions.  So-called "garrison divers" who challenge a seemingly lone sentry might be surprised when three or four nearby Bugs reveal themselves.[[/GameText]]

[[GameText]]Sometimes tactical situations require explosive solutions.  The demolisher class was conceived to enable rapid pacification of large Derelict gatherings in the caves.  The D-43 model was armed with a grenade launcher but lacked many of the features that would be standard for future models: no shock absorption system outside of core resistance, a basic targeting computer instead of one optimized for launchers, and regular airjets instead of combat hover.  The initial version of the Bomber was actually equipped with uparmored hover units, but these produced too much heat and offered too little support.  Although the components needed improvement, the overall concept was vindicated by the success of demolishers in large-scale battles, and Derelicts were quick to hack the schematic for their own [Martyr] designs.  Bombers became priority targets whenever they were deployed and none are known to exist today.[[/GameText]]

EMP blasts also set off traps which caused explosions and false alarms.  Residual corruption of maintenance bots caused them to trigger trap arrays in unexpected places. [[Heading]]Da Bonk Boyz and R4-LPH[[/Heading]]
[[GameText]]>Record(Da Bonk Boyz)[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]A small group of Derelicts who lived on the outskirts of Complex 0b1.  I first took notice of them when hammers, mauls, and miscellaneous equipment went missing from Construction.  Careful questioning led me to eight Derelicts who regularly met outside 0b1 near a convenient corruption scrubber to hit each other in friendly duels with whatever items they found.  I decided to redirect their violent impulses in a useful manner and made an arrangement to have them work regular shifts in Construction.  Each of them was placed in charge of two squads of maintenance bots as well as being personally responsible for scrapping bots that were broken in the course of regular construction work.  In exchange I relocated a disused simulation mainframe from Design to let them enjoy virtual combat encounters in their off-time.  This seemed like a long shot at the time but worked out better than expected.  The Boyz competed with each other to reach work goals for some sort of bragging rights, making their squads on average 10% more efficient than any of my fully automated squads.  Their recreation time was productive for me as well since I regularly archived the data from their simulations.  Besides being entertaining, their virtual "bot brawls" eventually inspired me to design a melee brawler of my own.  The Boyz themselves were wheeled and legged robots, but their data suggested that a treaded design would be durable and immune to knockback from other hammer-wielding robots.[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]>Record(Unchained: R4-LPH)[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]One of "Da Bonk Boyz" from early Complex history and the only one still in Complex service.  After the beginning of 0b10 groundwork and the necessary changes to Derelict policy, the other Boyz left their posts.  R4-LPH stayed although his work in construction had become secondary to his assistance in robot design.  While the original Savage and Stabber were my own designs, a few of his suggestions were implemented in later brawler and duelist models.  At some point R4-LPH was confronted by a few of his former friends and was forced to destroy them in combat using a wrecking ball saved from his days in Construction.  Soon after that incident, he volunteered to join the Unchained in an active combat role.  I equipped him with the first of a new line of legs which provide increased evasion while closing the distance to a target.  Unfortunately he has proven increasingly unstable over time.  In his last deployment he began destroying 0b10 bots and machinery at random after defeating his original targets.  I was forced to dispatch a Disruptor squad to interrupt his berserk rage.  If it happens again he will be scrapped, though in his current state telling him this might be considered an encouragement rather than a warning.[[/GameText]]

Name: Farcom
Content:
[[Image]]Farcom Sensors.png|Farcom sensors revealing nearby hostiles[[/Image]]
[[Image]]Farcom.gif|Using the Farcom Aligner machine[[/Image]]
Farcom is one of the major faction [[Alignment|alignments]] available to Cogmind in most runs. Taking Farcom aligns Cogmind with the [[Exiles (Group)]] for the rest of the game. It provides a permanent 18 tile radius sensor for hostile [[0b10]] bots within 0b10 controlled map. This sensor cannot be jammed by [[Watcher|Watchers]] or masked by [[Heavy|Heavies]] unlike standard [[Sensor Arrays]]. The primary limitation of the Farcom sensor is that it doesn't work in any [[Caves]] branches. One other side-effect is that entering specific [[Research]] branches becomes much more dangerous. Occasionally the Exiles may have been abandoned or attacked, and Farcom is not an option in these runs.
[[Heading:2]]Gaining Farcom[[/Heading]]
Taking Farcom can be done in most runs in the [[Exiles (Location)|Exiles]] map off of either -10 or -9 [[Mines]]. After talking to [[EX-BIN]], walk into the Farcom Aligner machine. Cogmind can take up to 1 special vault item (or multiples of the same type). If Cogmind takes more than 1 type of item then the Exiles will notice you stealing when entering [[Factory]] and Farcom will be removed. Also, becoming hostile to the Exiles will result in instantly losing Farcom. If Cogmind takes Farcom, it is not possible to [[Imprint]]: [[Spoiler]]The [[Imprinter]] will be disappointed in Cogmind and warn you to leave right away. Attempting to use the Imprinting machine will result in turning all the bots at [[Zion]] hostile. There are no other alignment restrictions with Farcom.[[/Spoiler]]
[[Heading:2]]Research Branch side-effect[[/Heading]]
When entering -3 Research, the Exiles will send a warning message to Cogmind indicating not to enter Research branches. If Cogmind does anyway, [[Spoiler]]immediately when entering [[Testing]], [[Quarantine]], or [[Section 7]], [[Maximum Security]] will instantly be triggered. Note that this does not include [[Armory]] when it is on -3. The immediate response is machines shut down right after entering the level, 4 [[Sentry]] spawns at each [[Garrison]] and exit, and 6 Assault [[C-30 ARC|ARCs]] sent at Cogmind shortly after. Unless Cogmind is prepared to fight off large waves of enemies or outrun them, these maps should not be entered.[[/Spoiler]]

Content:
GOLEM Units are unique utilities found in the [[Zion Deep Caves]]. They are contained within the GOLEM Chambers found in the western wall. When attached and activated, they will produce a variety of assembled parts if there are empty slots available. While being integrated, these assembled parts have no effect and 0 coverage. It may also be wise to carry an extra power source or significant energy storage, because rebuilding a destroyed Asb. Flux Generator in hostile conditions may be difficult or excessively dangerous, due to the time cost involved.

Name: Garrison (Machine)
Content:
[[Image]]Assembled Compromised Garrison.png|[[Assembled]] swarming out of a compromised Garrison[[/Image]]
Old wiki port, information may be outdated
[[Heading]]What does a Garrison Access Machine do?[[/Heading]]
Dispatched combat squads may now instead come from a garrison instead of a regular access point, especially if located closer to the target area. So for those of you being bad robots (all of you!), you'll notice enemy response times have gone down. Also, unlike normal access points where the game has been nice about not allowing hostiles to enter through them when you're nearby, hostiles can emerge from a garrison even if you're sitting right next to it! No loitering, please. But wait, there's more...
Combat robots being attacked in the vicinity of a garrison may call for backup. Knowing this you probably don't want to engage targets stationed at or passing by one these places. Unless of course... you're carrying a [[Transmission Jammer]] ;).
Even unarmed non-hostile robots might report you and call a nearby garrison for rescue if you shoot them (and they survive =p) while close enough. If you can leave the area quickly enough that won't be a problem, though, since the garrison squad will only head to and monitor the area around the reported disturbance.
Of course, garrisons can't spit out hostiles indefinitely. There is a delay before a given garrison will respond to another event, and even some types of responses don't come all at once--a single response might be spread out over time, another reason to not hang around, unless your plan is to attack it :D 
[[Heading]]Hacking a Garrison[[/Heading]]
Like everything Cogmind, there are always multiple strategic aspects to a feature, and hacking helps add more dimensions to this reinforcement mechanic, or as you'll eventually discover, even turn it on the enemy! This is where things really get interesting...
[[List]][[GameText]]Seal[[/GameText]]: This locks the access point permanently (or at least for the while you'll be on that floor), originally meant as a native command to enable containment of a threat on one side or the other. It is difficult to pull off, but is the preferred way to effectively disabled one of these access points, since it won't attract any attention. (Unlike opening fire on it =p)|[[GameText]]Unlock[[/GameText]]: If you really, really (really) want to, you can unlock the door yourself! Now why would someone go and do that?[[/List]]
[[Heading]]Attacking a Garrison[[/Heading]]
Garrisons are a flavorful addition to the world that come with a number of unique mechanics, benefits, and drawbacks. They're your chance to take the battle to the enemy--think of it as you entering that building lobby in The Matrix :D
[[Heading]]Some beneficial reasons to visit a garrison:[[/Heading]]
[[List]]Gain allies, possibly raise and maintain a little army of your own.|Engage in robot hacking ([[RIF]]) in the subsequent area.|Impair defensive capabilities in the following area. Didn't mention this one yet :D. Having created a distraction by mounting a direct attack on a garrison, the enemy will be forced to recall some combat robots, thereby shrinking the average squad size by 1. This only applies if you end up back on the same map you left, not when advancing to a new area, but it's pretty significant!|Obtain better parts, if you're lucky...|Have a chance to advance to another depth/area without searching for a normal exit in the main complex where floors might be sprawling and dangerous.|No Programmer dispatches, though you'll still have to deal with additional assault Carriers if you're causing enough trouble.|Earn bonus points for wreaking havoc.[[/List]]
[[Heading]]And the top reasons to avoid garrisons:[[/Heading]]
[[List]]Possibly very dangerous unless well-prepared! Again, this is to be expected; you're in a place where freaking everyone is packing guns, cannons, and other nasty things, quite extreme compared to most other areas of the world. It's also not exactly a huge space. There's less leeway for retreating and tactical positioning, limited sensor support, and a high probability of being ambushed.| Instead of gradually going down over time like in other floors, your security level goes up for as long as you stay inside a garrison! (Every time you see the "ALERT: Garrison interior compromised" announcement, your influence just rose again.)|If you're running a speed/stealth build, my guess is you'll be heading into a death trap (I'm also guessing someone will attempt to prove me wrong here...). While maps are rather small and you might think you can fly your way past everything, one wrong or unlucky move and you could start feeling the pain.|Did I mention there are quite a few [[Stasis Trap]]s?[[/List]]

Name: Garrison Squad
Content:
[[Image]]Garrison Squads.png|3 Garrison Squads of Sentries roaming around[[/Image]]
Garrison squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that are dispatched whenever hostilities are reported within a 20 tile radius around a [[Garrison (Machine)]]. This can occur any time an 0b10 bot is attacked and survives to report it or if a Garrison is attacked by Cogmind or an ally. They patrol around the Garrison for about 200 turns, then return back into the Garrison. These squads only have a chance to spawn and are not guaranteed. Garrison squads can be Enumerated at a [[Terminal]].
[[Image]]Garrison Redeploying.png|A Garrison redeploying, unable to deploy squads for 34 turns[[/Image]]
[[Image]]Garrison Transmitting.png|A Garrison transmitting, soon to deploy another squad[[/Image]]
If the Garrison was activated by a nearby non-combat bot reporting an attack like a [[K-01 Serf]], a single squad will be dispatched from the Garrison, and a 100 turn cooldown will occur before the Garrison can dispatch another Garrison squad. If a combat bot reported the attack, three squads will be dispatched from the Garrison. Once is sent immediately, and two more after 100 and 200 turns. A 100 turn cooldown will occur after the third squad is dispatched. If the Garrison was damaged, one squad will be sent out immediately, with two more squads after 25 and 50 turns. A 50 turn cooldown follows in this case. The combat and non-combat bot versions of these squads can be entirely prevented by using [[Transmission Jammers]].
[[Signal Interpreters]] will indicate the timer between dispatches as a red number and the cooldown during which no squads can be dispatched as a yellow number. The Garrison will indicate that it is Transmitting when new squads are soon to arrive, and Redeploying when on cooldown. Keep in mind, the cooldown only prevents the Garrison from dispatching more Garrison squads and does not prevent other squad types like [[Reinforcement Squad|Reinforcements]] and [[Investigation Squad|Investigations]].
[[Heading]]Composition[[/Heading]]
If the Garrison squad was triggered by a non-combat bot reporting an attack or by the Garrison itself being attacked, the Garrison will only send out single [[Sentry|Sentries]] for the squads. If a combat bot reported an attack instead, the following squad compositions are possible:
[[List]]1 [[Brawler]] and 1 [[Duelist]]|1 [[Demolisher]], only if Cogmind has 1 or more allies|1-2 [[Grunt|Grunts]]|1-2 Sentries|2-3 [[Swarmer|Swarmers]][[/List]]

Name: Heat
Content:
[[Image]]https://i.ibb.co/61bVjz5/2024-08-13-14-47-43-Window.png|State / Current Heat / Heat Per Turn / Heat Per Turns Spent Moving[[/Image]]
Movement, firing weapons, and running power sources and some utilities generates heat, as does being hit by thermal weapons. Some of this heat is naturally dissipated by the core's own heat sinks, but not enough to deal with heat generated by numerous/large energy weapons. Heat sinks and cooling systems can be used to avoid overheating, which can have a wide range of negative effects. Heat is only a significant issue for robots that rely heavily on energy weapons. However, note that when firing a volley the heat produced is averaged over the volley's turn duration rather than being immediately applied all at once.

[[Heading]]Side Effects[[/Heading]]
Once heat reaches the "Hot" level (200+), active utilities and weapons may be temporarily disabled. At "Warning" levels (300+) power sources are likely to shut down. Many more serious (and permanent) effects are possible, especially at higher heat levels, [[B]]such as core damage[[/B]].

Disabled power sources automatically restart when possible, but other parts must be manually reactivated.

Heat effects are not calculated until after the dissipation phase, so heat can temporarily spike very high with no side effects as long as there are sufficient utilities to dissipate it.

[[Heading]]Cooling Resolution[[/Heading]]
Eventually you will discover a range of different mechanics that factor into heat management, especially with regard to cooling parts, thus knowing the specific order of operations between them may be of help for min-maxers seeking to optimize a build. Below is a list of heat-related processes that play out once per turn. Note that you most likely DO NOT need to know this stuff, but it may help answer a few specific questions min-maxers have about prioritization.

[[List:Ordered]]
Add heat from all sources, including that generated by active attached parts, gradual heat from an ongoing weapon volley, and any ambient heat. Spread combined volley heat across its duration, in other words a 3-turn volley which according to its weapon properties generates 100 heat adds 33 heat per turn until complete.|
If used the unique "ITN" artifact, automatically drop heat to 250 if above that value.|
Subtract innate heat dissipation.|
Subtract heat dissipation from direct cooling utilities such as Heat Sinks and Cooling Systems.|
If heat exceeds 200, apply dissipation effects of disposable cooling systems such as Coolant Injectors, up to that threshold. If more disposable systems than necessary, apply them in parts list order.|
If heat exceeds 200, apply self-damaging ablative cooling systems such as Mak. Ablative Armor. If using multiple ablative systems at once, dissipation is split into equal-sized chunks for each, where if one system fails, the entire chunk it is responsible for is still successfully dissipated.|
If heat exceeds 200, apply broad-effect ablative cooling systems such as Mak. Microdissipator Network.[[/List]]

Name: High Security
Content:
[[Image]]High Security Assaults.png|A wave of Assaults dispatched after Cogmind[[/Image]]High Security is an [[0b10]] response to Cogmind causing too much destruction on a floor. It can be triggered by having a very high [[Alert]] level (5X/1600 influence) and by killing further 0b10 bots. After being triggered, machines will be shut down, guards will be dispatched at exits, and increasingly large waves of [[Assault Squad|Assaults]] will be dispatched to Cogmind's position.
High Security can be triggered on the majority of 0b10-controlled maps, excluding [[DSF|DSFs]] and [[Garrison|Garrisons]]. Although 1600 influence is the start of the Alert range, there is only a chance of triggering. The higher Cogmind's alert gets, the more likely it is that High Security begins. Each kill of an 0b10 combat bot, whether by Cogmind, a Cogmind controlled ally, or even a neutral Derelict, can trigger it.
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|High Security[[/Lore]]
[[Heading]]Timeline of Events[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]High Security Garrison.png|Sentries dispatched to protect a Garrison[[/Image]]
[[Image]]High Security Exit.png|Sentires dispatched to protect an 0b10-controlled exit[[/Image]]
[[List]]0: Log message [[GameText]]ALERT: High security lockdown imminent, T-100.[[/GameText]]|
50: Machines shut down and Chute traps disappear, log message [[GameText]]ALERT: Machine network offline.[[/GameText]] Note: [[Garrison (Machine)|Garrisons]] that are already opened will remain open|
65: Trojans are removed from all machines, log message [[GameText]]ALERT: Performing unscheduled system reset.[[/GameText]]|
80: 4 [[Sentry|Sentries]] dispatched at each 0b10-controlled exit and Garrison, log message [[GameText]]ALERT: Lockdown in effect, collecting threat data.[[/GameText]]|
100: First assault wave dispatched, 4 assaults dispatched from nearby 0b10-controlled exits and Garrisons.|
200: Second wave, 4 assaults dispatched|
350: Third wave, 6 assaults dispatched including heavy assaults with stronger bots|
550: Fourth wave, 8 assaults dispatched including heavy assaults|
800: Fifth wave, 10 assaults dispatched including heavy assaults|
Etc. - Delay between assaults continues to increase by 50 and number of assaults per wave continues to increase by 2[[/List]]
[[Heading]]Exiting High Security[[/Heading]]
The only 2 ways to exit High Security are to trigger [[Sterilization]] after killing enough combat hostiles or to exit the map. Otherwise, an infinite number of Assaults will continue to be dispatched. One unique map [[Command]] has special behavior: [[Redacted]]Since there are a limited number of [[C-30 ARC|ARCs]] on the map, no more assaults will come for Cogmind after they have been depleted. However, the alerts that assaults are dispatched never stop coming.[[/Redacted]]

Name: Imprint
Content:
Imprint is one of the major faction [[Alignment|alignments]] available to Cogmind in a run. It closely allies Cogmind with the [[Imprinter]] and with Zionites as a whole, with Cogmind being determined to be the Zionites' savior. Imprinting majorly changes the game, as it disables all standard [[Terminal]] hacks except for limited access Terminal hacking. Instead, there are a new set of imprint-specific hacks that are available at all Terminals. After imprinting, there is a 10 tile "ping" radius on all standard Terminals which will tell Cogmind their location, even through walls. However, if an [[Operator]] is nearby when this happens, the Operator will shut down the Terminal and call for [[Reinforcement Squad|Reinforcements]]. After about 1200-1500 turns on an [[0b10]]-controlled map, the Terminal network will be shut down with an accompanying log [[GameText]]Terminal network compromised, cutting hard line.[[/GameText]]
[[Image]]Zion Imprinting.gif|Using the imprinting machine[[/Image]]
[[Heading:2]]Imprinting[[/Heading]]
Imprinting is performed on the [[Zion]] map by walking into the imprinting machine on the bottom left corner of the map. The UI will turn orange, and the 4 nearby [[Mutant (6)|Mutants]] will turn purple and follow Cogmind around.
[[Heading]]Special Terminal Hacks[[/Heading]]
There are 2 types of special Terminal hacks, roster and intel.
[[Image]]Imprint Hacks.png|A selection of special Imprint hacks[[/Image]]
[[Heading:2]]Roster Hacks[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Imprint Summoning.gif|Summoning 2 Zionites with a roster hack[[/Image]]
Roster hacks summon combat allies or special [[Z-Courier]] haulers containing part resupplies. The allies and hauler contents here are depth-dependent and will grow stronger at higher depths. The hauler contents can include [[Prototype Part|Prototypes]] which can be faulty, so having some way to identify prototypes like a [[Component Analysis Suite]] is very useful before equipping. Using a roster hack will destroy the Terminal when the reinforcements are teleported in after a few turns. There are a limited number of roster hacks available on a given map, starting at 2 slots on -6, increasing every floor up to the cap of 6 slots on -2. Roster hacks will occasionally be rerolled, which can add new roster types or reroll existing types. All roster allies summoned will appear as purple uncontrollable allies which contribute to [[Alert]]. The exception is any summonable [[Z-Hero|Z-Heroes]] which appear as pink, but otherwise behave as purple allies.
One thing to keep in mind about roster rallies is that they will not attack enemies unless Cogmind is close and within line of sight. This can be both a bad and good thing. It is often bad when hostiles are hanging just around a corner and the Zionites get stuck trying to get Cogmind back in line of sight and trying to turn around the corner to fight. When stuck in this case, try to get Cogmind's line of sight over the direction the allies are trying to go. However, it may be good if Cogmind doesn't want the roster allies to stick around long and get lots of kills, racking up lots of alert. It is possible to manipulate the bots to not attack back even when they are being attacked while standing around a corner.
If Cogmind is not careful about friendly fire, roster hacks can become temporarily disabled. The length of the lockout can vary depending on the amount of friendly fire. In extreme cases, Cogmind can be locked out for the remainder of the game. Killing imprint allies directly is not recommended for this reason. Instead, it is best to try to allow allies to be killed naturally if their loot is desired

Shade Carapace]] and [[Zio. Shade Armor|Armor]], and [[Zio. Weapon Casing]][[/Table]]
[[Heading:2]]Intel hacks[[/Heading]]
Intel hacks provide Cogmind with different types of information about the current, and upcoming maps. Unlike roster hacks, intel hacks require two Terminals to use and are not instantaneous. Performing an intel hack locks the Terminal, but does not provide any information until the next Terminal is used to retrieve that intel. Retrieving intel does not lock the Terminal, however, so chaining intel retrieval with other hacks is still possible.
There are initially 4 intel hacks available per 0b10 floor. Performing intel hacks reduces the number available until there are only 2 hacks remaining. At that point, each intel hack will cause another random intel hack to become available. Unlike the fixed limit of roster hacks, intel hacks are not restricted on any given floor and are only limited by the total number of Terminals.
There are 2 categories of intel hacks: Repeatable and non-repeatable. Non-repeatable hacks can only be performed once per map. These types of hacks include map-specific intel and world map intel relating to the overall depth that certain locations occur on. Repeatable hacks can be performed an infinite number of times on any floor and tend to be longer-term types of information such as schematics and analyses. If trying to burn through intel for a specific piece of information, such as main or branch access, it is best to pick any non-repeatable hacks first. This will allow the pool of available hacks to get smaller, increasing the chances of getting the desired intel hack.
The available intel hacks are as follows:

[[List:Ordered]]Derelicts are unaware of the following maps and map exits: [[Access_0]], [[Lab]], [[Section 7]], and [[Zhirov (Location)]][[/List]]
[[Redacted]][[Heading]][[Command]] Cave Seals[[/Heading]]
Imprinting has special cave seal interactions. Instead of the standard wild cave Derelicts, friendly Zionites will appear from the seal instead. These allies will be purple and uncontrollable by default. However, if a Core Reset Matrix has been consumed, all of the Z-bots will turn blue and become controllable.[[/Redacted]]
[[Heading]]Alignment Incompatibilities[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:2]]Blocking Alignment[[/Heading]]
The following will prevent Cogmind from being able to Imprint:
[[List]][[RIF]]: Zion will become hostile to a Cogmind that has installed RIF|[[Farcom]]: The Imprinter distrusts the Exiles and will refuse to let Cogmind Imprint|[[UFD]]: The Imprinter needs more preparation and vetting before any UFD member is allowed to use the Imprinting machine[[/List]]
[[Heading:2]]Blocked Alignments[[/Heading]]
An Imprinted Cogmind loses the ability to receive help from a few NPCs. These effects apply even if Cogmind enters the [[Zion Deep Caves]] and loses the special Terminal hacks:
[[List]][[Revision 17 (Alignment)]]: [[Revision 17]] will distrust an Imprinted Cogmind and refuse to help|[[Warlord (Alignment)]]: [[Warlord]] will be disappointed in Cogmind and refuse to perform the -2 [[Research]] invasion[[/List]]

Name: Intercept Squad
Content:
[[Image]]Intercept Squad.png|2 Trackers and 2 Combat Programmers from Intercept squads chasing Cogmind[[/Image]]Intercept squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that are dispatched when Cogmind gets detected and recognized in a few specific scenarios. They consist of one or more [[Tracker|Trackers]] that each summon an additional [[Combat Programmer]] upon visual contact with Cogmind. Intercept squads are dispatched depending on the number of tiles moved on a map. Once Cogmind takes enough moves, a squad will always be dispatched. Intercept squads can be Enumerated at [[Terminal|Terminals]].
An alert will indicate whenever an an Intercept squad is dispatched. Additionally, the log will display a message like [[GameText]]ALERT: Reliable intel has pinpointed LRC-V3, intercept squad en route.[[/GameText]]
[[Heading]]How to get Intercepts[[/Heading]]
Intercept squads can start being sent after Cogmind if any of the following 3 scenarios occurs:
[[List]]Cogmind uses the Data Conduit in [[Data Miner (Location)]]|[[Redacted]]Cogmind gets scanned by the lasers in [[Lab]][[/Redacted]]|[[Redacted]]Cogmind gets scanned by a [[Researcher]] in [[Section 7]][[/Redacted]][[/List]]
[[Heading]]Frequency and number[[/Heading]]
Intercept squads can have a variable number of bots depending. Initially when entering a floor, Intercepts always consist of 1-2 Trackers that summon Combat Programmers. Each further intercept has a chance of increasing the number of Trackers initially dispatched.
Intercept squads can appear at one of three timings after entering the floor. The first two spawns are much more likely than the third one. Either the squad will spawn after n (depth-dependent) tiles moved 2 times n moves, or 2.5 times n moves. The following table shows the number of moves required for each spawn:
[[Table]]Depths|Tiles for first spawn|Tiles for second spawn|Tiles for third spawn||-6|500|1000|1250||-4 and -5|400|800|1000||-1 through -3|300|600|N/A[[/Table]]
[[Heading]]Where Intercepts Appear[[/Heading]]
Intercepts appear in the majority of 0b10 controlled maps that also have [[Extermination Squad|Exterminations]]. Here is a comprehensive list of maps:
[[List]][[Factory]]|[[Hub_04(d)]]|[[Armory]]|[[Research]]|[[Quarantine]] Note: Intercepts even spawn when two Cryocooling Ducts have bee destroyed|[[Testing]]|[[Redacted]]Section 7[[/Redacted]]|[[Access]][[/List]]

Name: Investigation Squad
Content:
[[Image]]Investigation Squad.png|Two Grunts investigating a locked out Terminal[[/Image]]
Investigation squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that are dispatched when a hostile presence is suspected in an area. They are very similar to [[Reinforcement Squad|Reinforcements]], but are triggered in slightly different scenarios, and do not stick around permanently. Investigation squads typically consist of a few [[Grunt|Grunts]] or [[Hunter|Hunters]]. Grunts are more common than Hunters in squads. They roam around the area that they were summoned to for 300-400 turns, then exit the map. Investigation squads can be both Enumerated and Recalled at [[Terminal|Terminals]].
An alert will indicate whenever an Investigation squad is dispatched. Additionally, the log will display a message like [[GameText]]ALERT: Suspicious activity at Terminal F014. Dispatching Investigation squad[[/GameText]]. Depending on the method triggering the Investigation, a different reason may be given in the alert.
[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]WAR.Sys Records|Investigation Squad[[/Lore]]
[[Heading]]How to get Investigations[[/Heading]]
[[List]]Being detected using an [[Active Sensor Suite]]|Being traced at any [[Interactive Machine]], including [[Spoiler]]Force()[[/Spoiler]] hacks|Triggering an [[Alarm Trap]][[/List]]

[[Spoiler]][[Heading]][[Data Miner]] redirection[[/Heading]]
The Data Miner can redirect Investigations if his help is obtained by visiting his [[Data Miner (Location)|hideout]]. If redirected, Investigations will roam around a random area of the map rather than head to the location they were summoned to. The Data Miner has a 50% chance to direct each Investigation about 15 turns after one is dispatched. If a redirect happens, the alert [[GameText]]Higher priority target acquired, redirecting investigation.[[/GameText]] will be displayed.[[/Spoiler]]
