Name: Latent Energy Streamer
Content:
The Latent Energy Streamer uses a unique mechanic called latent energy to fire. At maximum latent energy capacity (100), the true damage potential is 90-100, with 1% disruption and +4 salvage.
[[Heading]]Latent Energy[[/Heading]]
Latent Energy is present all around the map but only in generally small quantities. The most latent energy is present in the various machinery. This means that the Streamer tends to be unimpressive in [[Caves]], but much stronger in [[0b10]]-controlled locations. Each type of machine has a different amount of latent energy it can provide to the Streamer. Generally, larger machines provide more latent energy. Attaching the Latent Energy Streamer allows visualization of how much latent energy is in an area.
[[Image]]Latent Energy Visualized.png|Latent energy visualized[[/Image]]
Latent energy will gradually return to an area after being used to power the Streamer. Generally, all latent energy will be restored within about 30 turns. Some explosive machines will either become destabilized or explode instantly when used to power the Streamer. Any resulting destruction will contribute to Cogmind's [[Alert]] level.

Name: Lightpack 2.0
Content: Each time a part is added to inventory, there is a chance that the Lightpack will lose a random part. When this happens, the log will display a message [[GameText]][Item] swallowed by quantum anomaly within Lightpack 2.0.[[/GameText]] Occasionally, the same part may be spit out later with another message [[GameText]]Quantum anomaly discharges [Item].[[/GameText]]. These effects occur more frequently when the inventory is more full.

Name: Locations
Content:
Locations in Cogmind are unique styles of maps to visit. The main floors (Scrapyard, Materials, Factory, Research, and Access) are always located on the same depths every run. These main floors often can be visited in multiple depths. Branches, on the other hand, are typically found on only a single depth per-run and are often mutually exclusive with other branches. For example, Mines can always be found on -9, but Storage may also appear on -9, forcing a decision about which branch to take, or whether to take one at all.
The majority of maps are randomly generated, meaning no two runs or two depths will have the exact same layout. However, the overall structure of each location type is very similar. Some maps tend to be more open with large rooms and wide corridors, while others are more maze-like with tiny rooms and many small corridors leading into dead-ends. A few branches are partially or entirely static in layout and tend to be much more predictable in contents than main floors.
Branches do not progress upward toward the exit and can often be harder than the main floors. However, branches can offer unique challenges and have similarly unique rewards that can dramatically change a run. This could be powerful unique items, special events, gameplay-altering alignment, or rare permanent buffs.
The following is a list of all locations in Cogmind:

Name: Matter
Content: Matter is used to attach components, and is consumed by ballistic weapons and launchers, which convert it to the appropriate type of ammunition. It can be salvaged from robot remains, though the available amount varies depending on how the robot was destroyed. Cogmind automatically recycles 5 matter from each attached part that is destroyed.

Name: Maximum Security
Content:
[[Image]]Maximum Security Assaults.png|A wave of Assaults and Sentries dispatched during Maximum Security[[/Image]]
Maximum Security is a special [[0b10]] response to a few specific threats that results in immediate shutdown of machines and increasingly large waves of [[Assault Squad|Assaults]] dispatched to Cogmind's position. Unlike the similar-behaving [[High Security]], Maximum Security is unrelated to [[Alert]] mechanics. Maximum Security can be triggered on most main and branch 0b10-controlled floors, excluding [[Command]], [[DSF|DSFs]], and [[Garrison|Garrisons]]. It can be triggered only by the following scenarios:
[[List]]Cogmind has taken [[Farcom]] and enters [[Quarantine]], [[Testing]], or [[Section 7]]|The [[Sigix Containment Pod]] is inserted into the [[Sigix Exoskeleton]] (instant)|Cogmind attaches the [[Sigix Exoskeleton]] and is spotted by an 0b10 combat bot[[/List]]
[[Heading]]Timeline of Events[[/Heading]]
[[List]]0: Log message [[GameText]]ALERT: [reason for Max Security]. Maximum security lockdown in progress.[[/GameText]]|1: Machines shut down, log message [[GameText]]ALERT: Machine network offline[[/GameText]]|2: Log message [[GameText]]ALERT: Performing unscheduled system reset.[[/GameText]]|3: 4 [[Sentry|Sentries]] dispatched at each 0b10-controlled exit and Garrison, log message [[GameText]]ALERT: Lockdown in effect, collecting threat data.[[/GameText]]|5/100: First assault wave dispatched, 6 assaults dispatched from nearby 0b10-controlled exits and [[Garrison (Machine)|Garrisons]]. The first wave will be dispatched after 100 turns for Farcom-triggered Maximum Security and 5 turns for other reasons.|105/200: Second wave, 6 assaults dispatched|255/350: Third wave, 8 assaults dispatched including heavy assaults with stronger bots|455/550: Fourth wave, 10 assaults dispatched including heavy assaults|705/800: Fifth wave, 12 assaults dispatched including heavy assaults|Etc. - Delay between assaults continues to increase by 50 and number of assaults per wave continues to increase by 2[[/List]]
[[Heading]]Exiting Maximum Security[[/Heading]]
The only 2 ways to exit Maximum Security are to trigger [[Sterilization]] after killing enough combat hostiles or to exit the map. Otherwise, an infinite number of Assaults will continue to be dispatched.

Name: Mechanics Achievements
Content:
Mechanics [[Achievements]] are earned by interacting with and/or using many of the mechanics of the game. They are largely used as a way to teach players about some of said mechanics. Most of them will be simply eventually be obtained by players as they make mistakes and/or learn new mechanics. 15 of the 72 Mechanics Achievements have hidden descriptions that are only revealed after completing them. The borders of Mechanics Achievement indicate their difficulty compared to other achievements of the same sub-type, with more "intense" borders meaning higher difficulty.

Name: Navigation Efficiency Matrix
Content:
The Navigation Efficiency Matrix (NEM) is a single use [[Alien Artifacts|Alien Artifact]] that will cause Cogmind to teleport at random intervals. When attached, the log message [[GameText]]Navigation Efficiency Matrix installed, partial failure due to system anomalies.[[/GameText]] will appear.
[[Image]]NEM.gif|Effect of the Navigation Efficiency Matrix[[/Image]]
[[Heading]]Teleport effects[[/Heading]]
An NEM teleport behaves similarly to a standard [[Transdimensional Reconstructor]] effect. All bots that are tracking Cogmind will instantly lose tracking, even including perfect tracking mechanics like [[Extermination Squad|Exterminations]] use. However, unlike a standard teleport, the NEM can teleport Cogmind through solid walls. This can sometimes be useful for escaping squads as it will place Cogmind out of sight in a different room. One downside of this effect is that teleporting can repeatedly trigger the [[Watcher]] [[Alert]] increase on sight, as it will forget Cogmind each time the teleport occurs.
[[Heading:2]]Frequency[[/Heading]]
There are 2 "timers" that can activate an NEM teleport. One is based on tiles moved, and the other is based on non-moving actions.
The non-moving actions timer will count up whenever Cogmind performs any action other than moving. This includes waiting in place, so it is not possible to avoid teleports altogether. The non-moving action timer will trigger every 36-48 actions.
The moving actions timer will count up for every move Cogmind makes. This timer is much shorter, and will occur 20-32 tiles moved.
[[Heading:2]]Distance[[/Heading]]
A single NEM teleport will move Cogmind anywhere between 8-12 tiles from the original location. If a [[Subatomic Replicator]] is used on the NEM and two are consumed, this effect doubles to 16-24 tiles moved.

Name: Overload
Content:
Overloading is a [[Game Mechanics|Game Mechanic]] available on [[Overloadable Parts]], primarily cooled (Cld.) parts, that allows for a temporary increase in effectiveness with additional heat costs and potential downsides based on the stability of the part. It is possible to perform for Power, Propulsion, and Weapon type items.
[[Heading]][[Overloadable Power|Power]][[/Heading]]
Some power parts (e.g. [[Cld. Ion Engine]]) support overloading. Overloading power causes the following changes:
[[List]]Doubled energy generation|Doubled heat generation|Chance to shut down for ~5-10 turns and be damaged ~30-40% of the maximum integrity, based on the Stability % stat[[/List]]
[[Heading]][[Overloadable Propulsion|Propulsion]][[/Heading]]
Some propulsion types (mainly [[Flight Units]] and [[Hover Units]]), e.g. [[Cld. VTOL Module]], support overloading. Overloading propulsion causes the following changes:
[[List]]Doubled energy cost|Tripled heat generation|50% additional support|Speed is calculated as if there are twice the number of active Flight/Hover units (e.g. an overloaded Cld. VTOL Module will gain an additional -3 speed modifier)|Overload propulsion has a chance to suffer 1 point of damage each move that the part is active or each melee attack, based on the Burnout % stat[[/List]]
One special case, the [[Potential Leg]], does not have any of the above effects except for the burnout damage. Overloaded Potential Legs instead have their base speed halved.
[[Heading]][[Overloadable Weapons|Weapons]][[/Heading]]
Some energy weapons (e.g. [[Cld. Pulse Rifle]]) support overloading. Overloading weapons causes the following changes:
[[List]]Double damage|Doubled energy cost|Tripled heat generation|Additional level of heat transfer (e.g. Medium (+37) is turned into High (+50)|Chance of negative effect based on Shot Stability %.[[/List]]
If an overload side effect occurs, one of the following effects will occur:
[[List]]Energy Bleed (~40% chance): Cogmind loses anywhere from 10-50% of total energy capacity|Heat Surge (~40% chance): Cogmind gains between 100 and 200 heat|Short Circuit (~20% chance): A random part breaks[[/List]]

Name: Patrol Squad
Content:
[[Image]]Patrol Squad.png|A patrol squad of Swarmers[[/Image]]
Patrol squads are typically [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that patrol between points on the majority of 0b10-controlled maps, as well as [[Caves]]. They can be composed of a variety of bot types, all with slightly different patrolling behavior. Most patrol squads appear at the start of the map and will not appear over time, with the exception of [[Search Patrol|Search Patrols]]. Their presence is generally unrelated to [[Alert]]. Patrols can be Enumerated at [[Terminal|Terminals]]. Their frequency varies based on the type of map, but generally they are more common the higher up in the complex Cogmind goes.
[[Heading]]Patrol Contents[[/Heading]]
The following are the possible contents of patrol squads. At -9 and above, a [[C-30 ARC]] can also make up a single patrol squad. If it encounters a hostile, it will open up to reveal the contents of any other random patrol squad composition listed below:
[[Table]]Depth|[[Grunt]]|[[Hunter]]|[[Programmer]]|[[Swarmer]]||-10|1 [[G-47 Trooper]] squad leader and 1 [[G-34 Mercenary]]|N/A|N/A|3 [[S-10 Pest]]||-9|1 [[B-36 Bruiser]], [[L-31 Rogue]], or G-47 Trooper squad leader and 1-2 G-34 Mercenary|N/A|N/A|3-4 S-10 Pest||-8|1 B-36 Bruiser, L-31 Rogue, or [[G-50 Soldier]] and 2 G-47 Trooper|1 [[H-55 Commando]]|N/A|3-4 S-10 Pest||-7|1 [[B-48 Gladiator]], [[L-41 Fighter]], or G-50 Soldier squad leader and 2-3 G-47 Trooper|1 H-55 Commando|1 [[P-60 Hacker]]|3-4 [[S-27 Virus]]||-6|1 B-48 Gladiator, L-41 Fighter, or [[G-67 Veteran]] squad leader and 2-3 G-50 Soldier|1-2 [[H-66 Slayer]]|1 P-60 Hacker|3-4 S-27 Virus||-5|1 [[B-60 Warrior]], L-41 Fighter, or G-67 Veteran squad leader and 2-4 G-50 Soldier|1-2 H-66 Slayer|1-2 [[P-70 Sage]]|4-5 S-27 Virus||-4|1 B-60 Warrior, [[L-61 Swordsman]], or [[G-73 Enforcer]] squad leader and 2-3 G-67 Veteran|2 [[H-77 Assassin]]|1-2 P-70 Sage|4-5 S-27 Virus||-3|1 [[B-74 Champion]], L-61 Swordsman, or G-73 Enforcer squad leader and 3 G-67 Veteran|2 H-77 Assassin|1-2 [[P-80 Master]]|3-5 [[S-43 Plague]]||-2|1 B-74 Champion, L-61 Swordsman, or G-73 Enforcer squad leader and 3 G-73 Enforcer|2 [[H-88 Terminator]]|1-2 P-80 Master|4-5 S-43 Plague||-1|1 B-74 Champion, L-61 Swordsman, or G-73 Enforcer squad leader and 3-4 G-73 Enforcer|2 H-88 Terminator|1-2 P-80 Master|4-6 S-43 Plague[[/Table]]
[[Heading:2]][[Armory]] Patrol Contents[[/Heading]]
[[Spoiler]]Armory has additional patrol types that can appear:
[[/Spoiler]]
[[Table]]Depth|Demolisher Squad|Duelist Squad|Specialist Squad||-4|1 [[D-63 Destroyer]] squad leader and 2 G-67 Veteran|3 L-61 Swordsman and 1 [[I-47 Archangel]]|2 [[X-72 Disruptor]], [[X-77 Beamer]], or [[X-82 Rainmaker]] and one [[E-15 Imp]]||-3|1 D-63 Destroyer squad leader and 2 G-67 Veteran|3 L-61 Swordsman and 1 I-47 Archangel|2 X-77 Beamer, X-82 Rainmaker, [[X-87 Electro]], and one E-15 Imp[[/Table]]
[[Heading]]Patrol behavior[[/Heading]]
There are essentially 2 types of patrol behaviors. ARC and Hunter squads are fast patrollers, which navigate between their patrol points at max or near max speed. They quickly move in and out of areas so they can be hard to avoid if in the way, but are easier to navigate around without waiting long periods of time. Grunts, Programmers, and Swarmer squads all patrol much slower. They meander along the way and spend far more turns resting than moving forward along their route. It is easier to run away form these types of patrols if you know they are coming, but they can clog rooms or hallways for long periods of time.

[[Heading]]Special patrol-summoning events[[/Heading]]
There are a few special events that can trigger patrol dispatches when already on a level.
[[Heading:2]][[Search Patrol|Search Patrols]][[/Heading]]
Search Patrols are a special type of patrol that is related to Alert. These squads can be dispatched if Cogmind generates a lot of non-combat Alert. They consist of a single [[C-30 ARC]] that roam across the entire map instead of just between two points like most patrols.
[[Spoiler]][[Heading:2]][[Lightning]] squads[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Lightning Squad.png|A Lightning squad patrolling Quarantine[[/Image]]
Lightning squads consist of 3 Lightnings and an [[I-47 Archangel]]. They can be summoned in one of two ways:
[[List]]Destroying a Hub machine in [[Hub_04(d)]]: 3 Lightning patrols will be dispatched to the map out of exits and Garrisons. They will roam in the general area of each remaining Hub.|Opening the [[Sigix Containment Pod]] chamber: A single Lighting patrol will be dispatched to the map if Cogmind breaches the Sigix chamber. It will patrol around the location of the Sigix room.[[/List]][[/Spoiler]]

[[Heading]]Earning points[[/Heading]]
Earning points is done in a variety of ways, including :
[[List]]Ascending through each floor (500 points for every evolution threshold crossed)|
Visiting regions (200 per map entered)|
Destroying robots (5 points per robot destroyed)|
Destroying stuff in general (depends on the value of what was destroyed)|
Obtaining [[Prototype Part]] IDs (20 points per unique Prototype Part ID, including any that might have been forgotten due to reasons like component data loss)|

The lore collection contains all lore records, dialogues and their source, as well as all analyses and the general robot type they are about. All start out hidden, and are revealed in the collection when found within the game world.
[[List]]

There are also a few records that are not part of the lore collection, mostly non-unique records from [[Caves|Cave]] outposts that contain Terminals.|

Except for csv files, this includes undiscovered records, making it possible to view how many records and dialogues remain to be found from certain sources. Name: Quantum Companion
Content:
The Quantum Companion is a unique talking melee weapon that is an upgrade to the [[Companion Sword]]. It can be obtained by either using a [[Subatomic Replicator]] on a Companion Sword or by using the Companion Sword for while. The Quantum Companion has all of the special effects that the base Companion Sword has with a higher frequency of occurrence and also has some new unique effects of its own.
[[Heading]]Special Effects[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]Effect|Description|Frequency||Materialization|The Quantum Companion will materialize in one of Cogmind's weapon slots within a few turns of being detached. If no slots are available, the weapon in the first slot will be detached to make room. Occurs even if the Quantum Companion is destroyed, in which case it will reappear with full integrity. The log message [[GameText]]Quantum Companion materializes via a weapon slot.[[/GameText]] will appear when this happens.|Always||Sensors|After some time in Quantum Companion form, the Quantum Companion will develop 12 range bot detection. Unlike typical sensors, these work on all bots without a [[Signal Interpreter]], even if they have the Scan Cloak trait.|Always||Surprise Attack|The Quantum Companion will "surprise attack" one additional target on a normal attack. The log message [[GameText]]Quantum Companion surprise attacks [target].[[/GameText]] will appear when this happens.|Common||Core Loss|The Companion Sword deals between 5-10 core damage directly to Cogmind's core on a normal attack. Can't be reduced by [[Core Shieldings]] or [[Defensive Utilities]]. Only happens when Cogmind attacks something with the Companion Sword.|Uncommon||Shadow Attack|A shadow clone of the sword attacks a hostile bot at range. Can occur even when not attacking. This attack cannot miss. The log message [[GameText]]Quantum Companion releases a shadow of itself that zips off toward [target].[[/GameText]] will appear when this happens. This attack deals 70-100 phasic damage.|Uncommon||Bot Disruption|A bot is instantly disrupted on a normal attack. As with normal disruption, a disrupted bot can be rewired as long as it isn't hacking immune. The log message [[GameText]][target] shuts down.[[/GameText]] will appear when this happens.|Rare||Redirected Attack|When attacked by a projectile, the Quantum Companion will redirect the attack back to the attacker. The log message [[GameText]]Redirected attack with Quantum Companion.[[/GameText]] will appear with this happens. 200 energy required for this effect.|Rare||Sever|A part is severed off of a bot on a normal attack. This effect can hit through the Dismemberment immunity, unlike standard Sever critical hits.|Rare||Sunder|This effect will instantly sunder a bot, similar to the [[Core Stripper]] on a normal attack. All parts are dropped between 1/3 and 2/3 integrity. Affected by the Dismemberment immunity. [[Heading]]Transformation[[/Heading]]
If a Subatomic Replicator is used on the Quantum Companion, it will transform into the [[Superquantum Companion]]. Unlike the base Companion Sword, this effect does not occur from use alone. This means that it is not possible to use a replicator to get from the base Companion Sword and also get the Quantum Companion. When this happens, the following game log message will appear: [[GameText]]Quantum Companion blips out of existence for a moment, then partially fades back in.[[/GameText]] The Superquantum Companion will also comment: [[GameText]]As you get more powerful, it's only fair that I, too, become godlike![[/GameText]]

Name: Reinforced Walls
Content:
Many areas are sealed off by various types of Reinforced Walls. These walls all have much higher than typical armor values and resistances to most common damage types. The common theme between them all is that they do not have any Thermal resistance. As such, Cld. thermal [[Energy Cannons]] are the ideal way to cut through many of these barriers. Unlike basic walls, reinforced walls will not collapse due to penetrating weapons.
There are two primary types of reinforced walls. Though they have different names, they behave functionally similarly. Orange doors block the main access to the blocked off area. These doors have a higher than normal armor value, but they tend to be lower than reinforced barriers. Reinforced barriers typically surround the remainder of the area to prevent digging in from the back side. In most maps, these have two times the normal armor level of walls. For example, an average Storage wall has an armor value of 24, so the reinforced barriers have an armor value of 48 on this map.

Name: Reinforcement Squad
Content:
[[Image]]Reinforcement Squad.png|2 Hunters in a reinforcement squad[[/Image]]
Reinforcement squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that are dispatched when a hostile presence is reported in an area. They are similar to [[Investigation Squad|Investigations]], but are triggered in slightly different scenarios, and typically stick around permanently. Reinforcement squads typically consist of a few [[Grunt|Grunts]] or [[Hunter|Hunters]]. [[Heavy|Heavies]] can call unique types of reinforcements that do not stick around forever and are made up of [[Cutter|Cutters]] or [[Specialist|Specialists]]. Reinforcements will roam around the area that they were summoned to permanently. They can be both Enumerated and Recalled at [[Terminal|Terminals]].
An alert will indicate whenever a Reinforcement squad is dispatched. Additionally, the log will display a message like [[GameText]]ALERT: Hostiles spotted, dispatching reinforcements to Terminal F003.[[/GameText]] Depending on the method triggering the reinforcement, a different reason my be given in the alert.
[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]WAR.Sys Records|Reinforcement Squad[[/Lore]]
[[Heading]]How to get Reinforcements[[/Heading]]
[[List]]Being detected by a Heavy on their [[Active Sensor Suite]]|Being reported by a [[Hauler]] carrying [[Prototype Part|Prototypes]] that is attacked|Being reported by an [[Operator]] at their associated Terminal|Being reported by a [[Researcher]] that witnesses Cogmind fire a weapon in their presence|Being reported by a [[U-05 Engineer]] being attacked while trying to perform repairs[[/List]]
[[Heading]]Reinforcement Contents[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]Depth|Grunt Squad|Hunter Squad|Heavy Cutter squad|Heavy Specialist squad||-10|1-2 [[G-34 Mercenary]]|N/A|N/A|N/A||-9|1-2 G-34 Mercenary|N/A|N/A|N/A||-8|2-3 [[G-47 Trooper]]|N/A|2-4 [[C-17 Slicer]]|2 [[X-57 Shotgunner]] or [[X-62 Marksman]]||-7|2-3 G-47 Trooper|N/A|2-4 C-17 Slicer|2 X-57 Shotgunner, X-62 Marksman, or [[X-67 Chaingunner]]||-6|2-3 [[G-50 Soldier]]|1-2 [[H-66 Slayer]]|2-4 C-17 Slicer|2 X-62 Marksman, X-67 Chaingunner, or [[X-72 Disruptor]]||-5|2-3 G-50 Soldier|1-2 H-66 Slayer|2-4 [[C-35 Carver]]|2 X-67 Chaingunner, X-72 Disruptor, or [[X-77 Beamer]]||-4|3-4 [[G-67 Veteran]]|2 [[H-77 Assassin]]|2-4 C-35 Carver|2 X-72 Disruptor, X-77 Beamer, or [[X-82 Rainmaker]]||-3|3-4 G-67 Veteran|2 H-77 Assassin|2-4 C-35 Carver|2 X-77 Beamer, X-82 Rainmaker, or [[X-87 Electro]]||-2|3-4 [[G-73 Enforcer]]|2-3 [[H-88 Terminator]]|2-4 [[C-57 Dissector]]|2 X-82 Rainmaker or X-87 Electro||-1|3-4 G-73 Enforcer|2-3 H-88 Terminator|2-4 C-57 Dissector|2 X-87 Electro[[/Table]]
[[Heading]]Heavy reinforcements[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Heavy Reinforcement Squad.png|A Heavy and summoned Specialist reinforcements[[/Image]]
Heavy-summoned reinforcements behave differently than other reinforcements. These reinforcements only stick around for about 150 turns before returning back to a nearby exit as opposed to staying permanently. Heavy reinforcement contents also depend on Cogmind's speed. If Cogmind is on a fast airborne propulsion type like hover or flight, Cutters will be dispatched far more frequently than Specialists. For all slower grounded propulsion types, Specialists are the most common summon type.
Heavy reinforcements are called more frequently if Cogmind is actively moving. If trying to avoid reinforcements, Cogmind should quickly exit the Heavy's sensor radius rather than spend turns moving inside the radius. If the Heavy is on a [[Security Rotation]] and currently moving, it may be a good idea to stand still until the Heavy has moved away to try to avoid reinforcements rather than to continue moving in detection range.

Name: Relay Interface Framework
Content:
[[Image]]Garrison RIF Installer 1.png|RIF Installer in a Garrison[[/Image]]
Relay Interface Framework, or RIF, is one of the major [[Alignment|alignments]] available to Cogmind in a run. It helps Cogmind to have much more control over [[0b10]] bots, both combat and non-combat. RIF comes with the downside of alienating several key [[Derelict]] factions, namely turning all Derelicts at [[Zion]] and [[Warlord (Location)]] hostile when passing their associated System Quarantine Field Array machines. RIF is also incompatible with the [[Core Reset Matrix]]. If Cogmind has used a CRM then it is not possible to gain RIF. If Cogmind uses a CRM after using RIF, then RIF will be entirely erased. Similarly, if Cogmind has [[Imprint|imprinted]], then the RIF will fail to be installed.
Installing RIF can be done at any [[Garrison]] by walking into a RIF Installer machine. These machines can be hidden behind emergency accesses and Phase Walls, but there are always 1-2 installers available per map. Doing so will grant several unique abilities:
[[List]]Alert Monitor: Know the ambient influence level while in 0b10-controlled areas.
 [[Alert]] is displayed near the top right corner of the HUD, showing both the numeric influence value and the number-letter classification.|Garrison Interface: Gain control over Garrison Access machines, making it easier to hack them, and also easier to escape once inside. Also automatically detects [[Garrison (Machine)|Garrisons]] and RIF Installers up to a range of 15.
All standard (non-manual) hacks at Garrison Machines will have a 100% chance to succeed. The 15-radius detection is very handy for finding new Garrisons to enter, as well as finding hidden RIF installers behind walls.|Coupler Protocols: Use [[Relay Couplers]] to interface with their respective robots.
Use [[Datajacks]] with Relay Couplers to perform special hacks at the cost of charges on the Couplers. See [[~/rif|this page]] for the full list of hackable bots as well as unique hacks applicable to each type of bot.|Additional RIF abilities: See [[~/rif|this page]] for the full list of abilities.|Special [[Wintypes|Wintype]] interaction: [[Redacted]]If Cogmind touches the intact 0b10 Conduit machine in [[Command]] while being RIF-aligned, the W4 Assimilated 0b10 win will be achieved without needing to destroy both phases of [[MAIN.C]] as is typically required.[[/Redacted]][[/List]]

Name: Revision 17 (Alignment)
Content:
[[Image]]Cetus Saving Revision 17.png|Saving Revision 17 in Cetus[[/Image]]
Rescuing [[Revision 17]] in [[Cetus]] allows for a minor faction [[Alignment|alignment]]. If this is done, [[Revision 17++]] will attack [[0b10]] on the -3 [[Research]] map along with a lot of friendly [[Revision|Revisions]] as allies.This alignment is incompatible with [[Imprint|imprinting]] and Revision will flee from an imprinted Cogmind out of fear of the [[Imprinter]]. In order for the alignment to take effect, Revision 17 must survive until Cogmind exits the map, all 8 [[Cetus Guard|Cetus Guards]] must be destroyed, and the Cetus Manufacturing Module machine must be intact.
[[Heading]]-3 Research Invasion[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Research Revisions.png|Revision 17++ with Revision allies[[/Image]]
[[Image]]Research Suppression Forces.png|Suppression forces dispatched to fight the Revisions[[/Image]]
200 turns after entering the map, Revision 17++ will lead a group of 4 Revisions to follow Cogmind. They are uncontrollable allies but do not generate any alert for Cogmind when attacking. The announcement text [[GameText]]Unknown forces entering zones 8R, 1R, 4T. Local Systems Malfunctioning[[/GameText]] will precede their coming. Squads of 4 Revisions will continue to appear from main access exits every 200 turns. Occasionally a Revision will shout [[GameText]]Recycler![[/GameText]] and turn hostile, although this may also be followed by [[GameText]]##MEMORY:RESET##[[/GameText]] to turn them friendly again. 500 turns after Revision 17 arrives, an alert [[GameText]]Research terminal network lockdown[[/GameText]] will appear, and all Terminals on the map will shut down (other interactive machines are unaffected). Another alert will show up 50 turns later: [[GameText]]Suppression forces dispatched. All non-combat units evacuate.[[/GameText]] After this message, squads of 2 [[Executioner|Executioners]] or [[Striker|Strikers]] and an [[C-30 ARC|ARC]] will start to appear from exits and roam the map, looking for hostiles. They will also spawn every 200 turns.
There are a few other side-effects of this event. One is that explosive machines will explode at random whenever Cogmind is nearby. This can be good when fighting enemies around explosive machines, but be wary of them when walking around the map or else they may surprise you at a bad time. Another is that mapgen is affected. [[Heavy|Heavies]] will not appear on a map that Revision 17 invades.

This event can be a great blessing or a curse depending on a lot of factors. Getting an escort of alert-free allies with other squads of allies roaming the map is great. They will clean up most of the map for you and can net some free prototype bot loot. Blocking Heavy spawns is incredibly useful here as well. The downsides can also be pretty major, however. Losing access to all Terminals by turn 700 can be very bad if Cogmind is on slow propulsion and has no exit intel and no form of terrain scanning. Trying to follow the spawning Revisions or suppression forces can lead to an exit, although it can be a bit unreliable. Another downside is that the Revisions will often create a ton of squads to appear right at the beginning of the event. Sometimes, large groups of [[Operator|Operators]] and alarm traps can all be triggered at nearly the same time. This can result in massive groups of hostiles to appear right in Cogmind's face with unlucky exit or [[Garrison (Machine)|Garrison]] positioning.

Due to a bug (fixed for Beta 15), going through a Garrison and looping back to -3/Research will cause the event to partially continue.[[Comment]]Apparently it was a bug?[[/Comment]]

Name: Scrap Engine
Content:
Scrap Engine is a unique [[Derelict]] part that can only be obtained by stealing from the [[Recycling#Scraplab|Scraplab in Recycling]]. It has the capability to create powerful constructs by combining many different parts into one. It can create power constructs of up to 4 slots, propulsion up to 8 slots, and weapons of up to 4 slots. When more of Cogmind's slots are dedicated to constructs, they will also get more powerful overall.
The Scrap Engine can create combinations of parts that would never be seen normally, such as energy cannons dealing kinetic damage with heat transfer, or 50 speed treads. Modifications to the constructs will only change a few stats at a time, so overall variability is extremely high when using the engine. Modifying a construct with a flight unit may result in a much higher speed, or it may dramatically reduce the integrity and support instead. Every part that is eaten can be a gamble, since the stats that are modified are random every time.
[[Heading]]Processing Parts/Inventory[[/Heading]]
The Scrap Engine can be fed parts by enabling it and standing on top of a part. Once eaten, a part will remain in the Scrap Engine's inventory until it is used for creating a new construct or for modifying an existing one. Up to 10 power, propulsion, protection, and weapons can be stored (counted separately for each part type). This inventory can be used as a pseudo-storage mechanism by preemptively eating a part and disabling the Scrap Engine to prevent use until later. This is more efficient than keeping parts in regular inventory, but is more restrictive since the parts used for modification can't be explicitly selected anymore. If over 10 parts of a given type is fed to the engine, the first part in the engine's inventory will be destroyed.
[[Heading:2]]Broken/Faulty parts[[/Heading]]
The output of the Scrap Engine is not negatively affected by inputting low-integrity, broken, or faulty parts. As such, it may be a good idea to feed these parts to the Scrap Engine instead of throwing them away or letting them become totally destroyed.
[[Heading:2]]Protection parts[[/Heading]]
Rather than going toward creating new constructs, protection is instead used to reinforce the Scrap Engine itself. The first time that a protection item is consumed, the Scrap Engine will turn itself into the [[Arm. Scrap Engine]], gaining more coverage and integrity. Every subsequent armor piece consumed will restore 100 Scrap Engine integrity.
[[Heading]]Creating constructs[[/Heading]]
If 2 power, 3 propulsion, or 4 weapons are stored in the engine's inventory at once, a new construct can be created by combining all of the parts into a new one. Duplicates of a part may be used in new constructions, but at least 2 unique parts must be involved in new construct creation. Note: There is a maximum of 1 power and 1 propulsion construct each at a time, but up to 4 weapon constructs can be created. New constructs are created with a mix of the stats of the original items put into them. The Scrap Engine will preferentially create new constructs as opposed to modifying existing ones.
[[Heading:2]]Naming[[/Heading]]
The names of constructs are generated from a combination of parts processed up to that point. For example, eating an [[Ion Engine]] and a [[Nuclear Core]] may result in a Nuclear-Ion Core. Further modifications may cause the name to change over time.
[[Heading:2]]Type[[/Heading]]
The initial type of a construct will be selected randomly from its original parts. This can cause unusual stats, such as treads much faster than typically seen when created in combination with a faster propulsion type like flight. Like names, the type of a construct can change over time with more modifications. Propulsion constructs gain all natural ability of the propulsion type, like a flight construct granting bot hopping, or a leg construct granting running avoidance bonuses.
[[Heading]]Modification[[/Heading]]
Constructs can be modified when at least 2 different parts are stored in the Scrap Engine's inventory at a given time. For example, 2 [[Aluminum Leg|Aluminum Legs]] would not result in modification, but 1 Aluminum Leg and 1 [[Imp. Aluminum Leg]] would cause a modification, as would 1 Aluminum Leg and 1 [[Flight Unit]].
Each time a construct is modified, 1-5 random stats (generally higher numbers for weapons, lower numbers for power and propulsion) are modified based on the parts that were just processed. Additionally, if there is a slot available, the modified construct may grow in size. The growing chance decreases as the construct gets bigger, so increasing from 1 slot to 2 slots is much easier than increasing from 2 to 3. Additionally, modifying a construct will restore about 1/3 of its integrity.
[[Heading:2]]Multiple slots[[/Heading]]
When parts evolve into multiple slots, some of the stats also scale proportionally. Resource costs always scale in accordance with the number of slots, as will integrity and coverage. Aside from that, primary aspects of the slot type like energy generation, support, and damage will all scale based on slot number. Stats that are percentage based, like overload burnout and critical hit chance, don't tend to change based on slot counts.
One unique interaction between multiple weapon constructs is the ability to merge. Rather than growing into a unique 2 slot weapon construct, sometimes 2 existing constructs will combine into a single multislot construct. The stats of both component constructs will be mixed together into the resultant construct.
[[Heading:2]]Special Abilities[[/Heading]]
Non-standard/special stats/abilities may be given to the constructs based on the type of part eaten. For example, eating a Cld. power source such as a [[Cld. Ion Engine]] may grant the ability to overload the power construct. These special stats/abilities may also be removed at random by further modifications. If a construct has a stat specific to a part type, such as overload on a flight/propulsion type, and changes to a new type that no longer supports it, such as treads, that special stat will be removed.
[[Heading:3]]List of special stats/abilities applicable to constructs[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]Slot|Stat/ability|Part to consume|Loss on type change?||Power|Overload|Any Cld. power source like [[Cld. Ion Engine]]|Never||Propulsion|Overload|Any Cld. flight or hover unit like [[Surge Thruster]]|Change to Wheel, Leg, or Treads||Propulsion|Siege Mode|Any 2 slot treads like [[Hvy. Siege Treads]]|Change to non-Treads||Weapon|Overload|Any Cld. energy weapon like [[Cld. Particle Cannon]]|Change to non-Energy Cannon/Gun||Weapon|Waypoints|Any guided weapon like [[Gui. Plasma Cannon]]|Never||Weapon|[[Spoiler]]Entropic damage type, additionally loss of integrity per shot[[/Spoiler]]|[[Spoiler]]Any Vortex weapon like [[Vortex Rifle]][[/Spoiler]]|Never[[/Table]]
[[Heading]]Part destruction[[/Heading]]
Unlike most parts, constructs are not always instantly destroyed when they run out of integrity. Any multislot parts are instead reduced in slot count and partially restored in integrity. Though the slot may be hard to regrow again, it does make constructs more resilient than they first might appear. The only exception to this rule is that a Vortex weapon construct will be entirely destroyed if it runs out of integrity due to being fired.
When any construct is forced to shrink in size via damage, fully destroyed, or manually removed, the Scrap Engine will be slightly damaged in the process, reporting that [[GameText]]Scrap Engine damaged due to network destabilization[[/GameText]].
[[Heading]]General Strategies[[/Heading]]
Scrap Engine tends to be a very powerful but often unreliable part. It can generate abnormally powerful constructs, far outstripping anything else available, and then snatch the positive aspects of them away and leave you with a weapon that generates 400 heat per shot. As such, making modifications with a lot of spare parts around is always a good idea to reduce the chance of getting stuck with a hard to use part. On the other hand, if a great construct is created, it may often be worth postponing further modifications until needed to repair integrity. Otherwise, the best qualities may be lost before long.
A good strategy is to approach the modifications with moderation. Going all in on thermal energy cannons may result in a high damaging high meltdown weapon, but may also spike your own heat generation past reasonable levels. Mixing in lower heat generating kinetic guns and cannons will tend to balance your weapons out with more sustainable energy and heat resource costs. Propulsion can be approached similarly. Eating a mixture of hover, legs, and tread propulsion will tend toward middle of the road constructs that aren't amazing at anything in particular, but you will rarely end up with the excessive highs and lows that can occur if only one type of propulsion is focused on. Additionally, being more lenient in what you eat will help keep constructs topped off on integrity.
For a higher risk higher reward approach, mixing extremes like treads and flight can result in some incredibly overpowered propulsion constructs. A primarily treads-orientated propulsion construct only needs a single good flight modification to take the speed down to close to the 40 speed range. However, bad modification can instead lose lots of integrity or support. Doing this is safer with a lot of spare parts to eat in case things go south. Another example of a beneficial extreme is combining high critical rate Hyp. weapons like [[Hyp. Gauss Cannon]] with meltdown criticals from thermal cannons. It is possible to create an abnormally high meltdown critical % weapon this way, at the risk of losing some weapon damage.
[[Heading:2]]Multi-projectile Weapons[[/Heading]]
[[Flak Gun|Flak Guns]] can produce excellent constructs due to their high projectile count. While some stats get reduced to compensate for the increased projectile count, it is still possible to achieve overall high damage and a high critical percent chance. It is even possible to go beyond the original weapon's projectile count (6 in the case of Flak Guns). Heat transfer is another good stat to apply to a large projectile construct. A high heat transfer combined with a high projectile count can melt bots nearly instantly.
[[Heading:2]]Miscellaneous Tips[[/Heading]]
[[List]]Have a stockpile of parts before equipping the Scrap Engine - Recycling is a good place to get a strong start on constructs due to the large number of different types of parts to eat, and the lack of big threats. If saving Scrap Engine for later, try to create a good sized loot pile ahead of time to get a head start on growing the constructs.|Don't go all in on EM damage - If all of your weapon slots are a single construct of EM type damage and you run into a [[Programmer]], you're going to have a rough time.|Be careful of destroying cover - Construct weapons tends to be much more powerful than typical weapons and will blow through walls right and left. This is good in some situations, but it can also leave you wide open to multiple angles of attack.|Leave a slot open for a [[Launchers]] - Dedicating all of your weapon slots to constructs makes it hard to deal with [[Swarmer|Swarmers]] or other large groups of hostiles.|Make careful [[Storage Unit|Storage]] selections - Larger storage units like [[Hcp. Storage Unit]] and above may be difficult to carry if flight and hover propulsion are eaten. Smaller storage units can be carried more easily without overweight penalties with a bad support modifications.|Modify constructs with slots open - If trying to grow a construct, make sure that an empty slot is available for growth. This is especially the case for weapon constructs. Even though two weapon constructs may occasionally merge into a single multislot construct, it is more reliable to grow the slot number by keeping one available.|Don't have more than 3 weapons in engine inventory at a time - If trying to grow a weapon construct in number of slots, having 4 parts in inventory with an open weapon slot will always result in a new construct being created rather than having the existing construct modified. It may take a little longer, but making sure to process only 2 at a time will ensure maximum modifications and the highest chance to grow a weapon construct in slot count. [[/List]]

Name: Search Patrol
Content: Search patrols are a unique type of [[0b10]] aligned [[Patrol Squad|patrol squad]]. They can be dispatched if Cogmind generates a lot of [[Alert]] from non-combat sources. This is primarily caused by being spotted by [[Watcher|Watchers]] or [[N-01 Spotter|Spotters]], guard bots like [[Sentry|Sentries]], or by being spotted by any combat hostile and then running away and losing tracking. If the Alert level is above the typical [[Assault Squad|Assault]] range of level 2/400 influence and Cogmind has gained the majority of the influence from these non-combat sources, there is a chance that one or more search patrols may be dispatched. If a search patrol is announced, influence will drop by 150. This will be accompanied by the alert [[GameText]]ALERT: Heightened foreign activity detected, dispatching search patrol.[[/GameText]] The alert will also indicate if multiple search patrols are to be sent out simultaneously. One or more ARCs will be dispatched after a few more turns. These ARCs behave similarly as regular patrol ARCs and have the same standard patrol contents within them. However, search squads will choose random points on the map to patrol to rather than having a fixed patrol route like all other patrols.

Name: Security Rotation
Content: Event occurring on 0b10 floors containing [[Heavy|heavies]]. During a security rotation, heavies will move to a new [[Security Squad|security]] position, and any heavies that have been eliminated will be replaced.

Name: Security Squad
Content:
[[Image]]Security Squad Heavy.png|A Heavy guarding a busy intersection[[/Image]]
Security squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that guard a single location and do not move unless alerted to hostiles. While they are called squads, security bots nearly always work alone and do not come in groups. Security bots tend to be guarding busy exits, corridors, [[Interactive Machine|interactive machines]], and part stockpiles. These squads are primary composed of [[Behemoth|Behemoths]], [[Heavy|Heavies]], and [[Sentry|Sentries]]. They tend to be present on the map when Cogmind enters, and don't appear in greater numbers as time goes on. The main exception to this is Heavies, which may be replenished by the [[Security Rotation]] event, although there will typically never be more than the initial number of Heavies on a map. Security squads can be Enumerated at [[Terminal|Terminals]], but only within a very limited radius of 20 tiles.

[[Heading]]Special security-summoning events[[/Heading]]
There are a few events that may trigger additional security guards to spawn on the map.
[[Heading:2]][[Cargo Convoy]] interruption[[/Heading]]
100 turns after a Cargo Convoy is disrupted, Heavies will begin to appear at 0b10-controlled exits and [[Garrison (Machine)|Garrisons]]. Every further 100 turns that pass, another Heavy will enter the map and head toward a nearby exit.
[[Heading:2]][[High Security|High]] or [[Maximum Security]][[/Heading]]
About 80 turns after entering High or Maximum Security, 4 Sentries will spawn from all Garrisons and 0b10-controlled exits.
[[Spoiler]][[Heading:2]][[Quarantine]] Cryocooling Duct failure[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Quarantine Guards.png|Quarantine Guards dispatched from a Garrison[[/Image]]
Cryocooling Duct machines may be sometimes found in Quarantine. These machines the ambient temperature of the map by default, but if 2 are destroyed, the ambient heat will rise up to +20. If this happens, all combat bots will be withdrawn from the map, and 12 [[Quarantine Guard|Quarantine Guards]] will be dispatched after about 100 turns. These bots will guard various high traffic parts of the map, while others patrol the map. A few will guard exits, as well as a Garrison, if one is present.[[/Spoiler]]

Name: Siege Mode
Content: Siege mode is an alternate state toggleable on all mutilslot treads. The transition in and out of siege mode takes 5 turns. During the transition, and for as long as the mode is active, [[Cogmind]] is immobile and the the treads cannot be disabled or removed. While in siege mode, non-melee attacks have +20% accuracy, coverage for all armor and heavy treads is doubled, any treads in siege mode get a free 25% damage reduction, no weapons suffer from recoil effects, and Cogmind is immune to instant part destruction from critical hits. [[Spoiler]][[Megatreads]], [[Tri-treads]],[[/Spoiler]] and any treads containing the word "siege" in the name are capable of high siege mode which instead gives +30% accuracy and 50% damage reduction.

Name: Sigix Containment Pod
Content:
The Sigix Containment Pod can be found in [[Quarantine]]. It has no gameplay effect by itself, but it enables the W3 [[Wintypes|Wintype]] and provides 5000 bonus score if carried to a win.
[[Redacted]]The Sigix Containment Pod can be put in the [[Sigix Exoskeleton]] in [[Section 7]] to create an allied [[Sigix Warrior]].[[/Redacted]]

Name: Sigix Corpse
Content: Provides 2000 bonus score if carried to a win.

Name: Sigix Exoskeleton
Content:
[[Image]]Section 7 Sigix Exoskeleton.png|The Exoskeleton room in Section 7[[/Image]]
The Sigix Exoskeleton is an [[Alien Artifacts|Alien Artifact]] that is only found in [[Section 7]]. Initially it is found on an unpowered [[Sigix Warrior]] named Sigix Exoskeleton in the bottom right corner of the hangar. If Cogmind has used a [[Core Reset Matrix]] (CRM), it is possible to enter the Exoskeleton, which dramatically alters gameplay for the rest of the current run.
[[Heading]]Unique effects[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:3]]Additional Core Damage[[/Heading]]
Roughly 1/3 of all damage dealt to the Sigix Exoskeleton is also dealt to Cogmind's core.
[[Heading:3]]Alien Weapon Damage Boost[[/Heading]]
All non-AOE attacks from Sigix weapons is doubled. However, this effect does not stack with things like [[Particle Chargers]]. The full list of affected weapons is as follows: [[Core Cannon]], [[Core Stripper]], [[Modified Sigix Sheargun]], [[Sigix Broadsword]], [[Sigix Shearcannon]], and [[Sigix Sheargun]]
[[Heading:3]][[Assembled]] Absorption[[/Heading]]
While the Exoskeleton is damaged, Assembled can be absorbed to repair it by 30 integrity when standing next to Cogmind.
[[Heading:3]]Core Dependence[[/Heading]]
Cogmind's core becomes dependent on the Exoskeleton. Even if Cogmind still has remaining core, if the Exoskeleton is destroyed the game will instantly be loss.
[[Heading:3]]Enhanced Hypermatrix Pings[[/Heading]]
Whenever entering a new floor with Assembled spawns available (all main 0b10-controlled floors, [[DSF|DSFs]], and [[Command]]), 6-8 Assembled will appear near Cogmind. Additionally, the Exoskeleton provides the CRM's hypermatrix ping detection and Assembled summoning ability at all times rather than only while at 1/3 core.
[[Heading:3]]Damage Reduction[[/Heading]]
The Exoskeleton provides a 50% damage resistance to all conventional damage types. This effect stacks with most [[Defensive Utilities]], but not with [[Resistance Devices]].
[[Heading:3]]Deactivation-Proof[[/Heading]]
The Exoskeleton cannot be deactivated by any means. This includes manual deactivation as well as [[Heat]]-based side-effects.
[[Heading:3]]Infowar[[/Heading]]
The Exoskeleton provides extremely powerful sensor intel in an 18 tile radius. Perfect bot detection, terrain scanning, part detection, and hidden door detection is granted within this radius.
[[Heading:3]]High Coverage[[/Heading]]
While not exactly a unique ability, the Exoskeleton has a uniquely high 30,000 coverage which dwarfs every other item's coverage in the game. Most typical forms of armor are entirely unhelpful with the Exoskeleton equipped.
[[Heading:3]][[Maximum Security]] Triggering[[/Heading]]
As soon as Cogmind is spotted by any combat hostile in most [[0b10]]-controlled maps, Maximum Security will be immediately engaged. One notable exception is that Maximum Security will not be triggered in Command. Non-combat [[Watcher|Watchers]] and [[Operator|Operators]] whose associated [[Terminal]] hasn't be destroyed will also trigger this effect.
[[Image]]Exoskeleton4x.png|Cogmind's new look[[/Image]]
[[Heading:3]]New Appearance[[/Heading]]
Cogmind will take on the Sigix Warrior artwork, or the uppercase X character in ASCII mode.
[[Heading:3]]Slot Fixing[[/Heading]]
When Cogmind enters the Exoskeleton, all slots will be reset to a total of 1 Power, 3 Propulsion, 3 Utility, and 2 Weapon slots. However, Cogmind gets some boosts in exchange for the slots. Cogmind gains 100 fixed energy capacity, and every slot above the new 9 total slot count provides 3 innate energy generation and 5 heat dissipation. Not counting [[Core Expander|Core Expanders]], a typical -3 Section 7 provides 36 energy and 60 dissipation while a -2 Section 7 provides 42 energy and 70 dissipation. Slots can be evolved as normal after entering the Exoskeleton, including using Core Expanders. As a side-note, a [[Core Physics Calibrator]] cannot remove the 3 propulsion slots and force removal of the Exoskeleton.
[[Heading:3]]UI Intel[[/Heading]]
There are 4 new pieces of intel located at the bottom of the inventory UI:
[[List]]Threats: Counts the number of active hostiles within sensor radius.|Components: Counts the number of parts on the floor within sensor radius.|Ping number: Counts the number of active but untriggered Assembled hypermatrix pings.|Tor distance: Lists the distance to the Tor, the Sigix spaceship. The number in thousands place varies based on the map, but up to the hundreds place, it roughly indicates how many tiles Cogmind must travel to get to the nearest [[Surface]] exit.[[/List]]
[[Heading:3]]Unique Interactions[[/Heading]]
Cogmind becomes indistinguishable from a Sigix Warrior to some NPCs. [[Warlord]] will turn aggressive upon seeing Cogmind during the -2 [[Research]] attack or when summoned via Command cave seals. [[MAIN.C]] has unique encounter dialogue and a special phase 2 encounter after the outer shell is defeated, summoning 4 additional [[M Shell/Atk]] and 4 [[M Shell/Def]]s to his side. The [[Architect]] will recognize Cogmind, but also has unique encounter dialogue.

Name: Splice Drone Bay
Content: Deploys [[Splice Drone|Splice Drones]].

Name: Squad
Content:
Squads are groups of one or more robots that work together as a single group. The majority of the squads in the game are [[0b10]]-aligned and thus hostile to Cogmind, but there are also [[Derelict]] squads that can be either friendly or hostile to Cogmind depending on the circumstances. Some 0b10 squad types can be recalled using a low success rate Recall hack at a [[Terminal]], but all squad types can be located using an Enumerate hack. The numbers of all squad types, although not their compositions or locations, can be revealed with the Enumerate(Squads) hack.
Typically, one bot per squad is designated as the [[Squad Leader]]. Squad leaders are the only bots that have the AI or order type active. All other bots are set to follow the squad leader. If the squad leader is destroyed, the other bots in the squad will either end up wandering around randomly, or leaving the map if their squad leader was already leaving the map.
[[Heading]]Types of 0b10 Squads[[/Heading]]
[[List]][[Assault Squad]] - Dispatched by 0b10 to target Cogmind directly. Unlike most squads that walk to their target, all Assault contents are contained with a faster wheeled [[C-30 ARC]]. Only get dispatched if Cogmind has [[Alert]] level 2 or higher (400 influence).|[[Coupling Squad]] - Dispatched periodically by 0b10 on any floors where [[Garrison (Machine)|Garrisons]] are available. Consist of a single [[Programmer]] carrying multiple [[Relay Couplers]] to restock a Garrison.|[[Demolisher Squad]] - Dispatched by 0b10 to eliminate large groups of hostiles, particularly [[Assembled]].|[[Extermination Squad]] - Dispatched periodically by 0b10 in [[Factory]] and beyond. They consist entirely of Programmers and will always head directly to Cogmind.|[[Garrison Squad]] - Dispatched by 0b10 Garrisons when combat occurs near that Garrison. Bots will roam around the area where the attack occurred, then return after 200-300 turns.|[[Spoiler]][[Intercept Squad]] - Dispatched by 0b10 directly to Cogmind only in a few special circumstances. Intercept squads consist of powerful [[Prototype Robot|Prototype]] bots designed to quickly neutralize Cogmind.[[/Spoiler]]|[[Investigation Squad]] - Dispatched by 0b10 to investigate an area of interest for 300-400 turns, then they exit the level.|[[Patrol Squad]] - Patrol between two points of interest at varying speeds. Unlike most other squads, patrols only appear at the beginning of a map, and more will not be replenished.|[[Reinforcement Squad]] - Dispatched by 0b10 to permanently reinforce an area of interest. Similar to investigations but do not leave their post and will patrol around the area they are summoned to forever.|[[Security Squad]] - Stand guard at intersections, on top of exits, and in rooms with part stockpiles or Machines. Will typically not move unless they are alerted of a hostile.|[[Surveillance Squad]] - Patrol between two points of interest similar to a Patrol squad, but made up of a single [[Watcher]] instead of combat bots.|[[Transport Squad]] - [[Hauler]] guarded by 0-2 [[Grunt|Grunts]] that transport parts from place to place. Empty Haulers may pick up parts fabricated at a [[Fabricator]].[[/List]]

Name: Sterilization
Content:
Sterilization is a special [[0b10]] response to Cogmind destroying too many combat bots on a single map. When activated, the ambient heat of the floor will be increased forever until Cogmind exits the map. As the heat increases, any remaining bots, parts on the ground, machines, and traps will all melt. Occasionally, machines will explode before they melt.
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Sterilization System[[/Lore]]
[[Heading]]Triggering[[/Heading]]
The number of bots to kill to trigger Sterilization depends on the map.
[[Table]]Map|Bots to kill||[[DSF]]|8||[[Materials]]|50||[[Storage]]|75||Most other maps|130[[/Table]]
[[Garrison|Garrisons]], [[Wastes]], and [[Command]] can not be Sterilized.
[[Heading]]Timeline of Events[[/Heading]]
[[List]]0: Non-combat bots start evacuating the map and head to 0b10-controlled exits, log messages [[GameText]]ALERT: Persistent threat exposed, engaging [map] sterilization system.[[/GameText]] and [[GameText]]ALERT: All non-combat units evacuation[[/GameText]].|100: Combat bots start evacuating the map and head to 0b10-controlled exits, log message [[GameText]]ALERT: All combat units evacuate.[[/GameText]]|300: Ambient heat increases by 10, log message [[GameText]]ALERT: Ambient heat levels +10.[[/GameText]]450: Ambient heat increases by a further 10|Etc. +10 heat for every 150 turns.[[/List]]
Note: Unlike most other maps, in [[Access]] bots are not evacuated. The evacuation-related alerts will not appear and the bots will continue to stay on the map as usual.
[[Heading:2]]Rapid Sterilization[[/Heading]]
DSFs have a unique rapid sterilization system that works much quicker than normal sterilization. Ambient heat increases begin only 20 turns after the initial announcement and occur every 15 turns after that.
[[Heading]]Part Melting[[/Heading]]
After Sterilization is triggered, parts will begin to melt every 30-40 turns and be destroyed instantly. Parts that are 200 integrity or greater are safe from melting. Parts with a lower integrity are more likely to melt than those with higher integrity. For example, [[Treads]] and [[Armor]] tend to last longer or be immune to melting altogether, while fragile processors will melt almost instantly. Parts only melt when within a 20-tile radius around Cogmind, so with a good enough speed, timing, and luck, it is possible to grab parts that would otherwise melt quickly in the heat.

Name: Style Achievements
Content:
Style [[Achievements]] are earned by reaching high statistics in some categories which usually require using an associated playstyle, or by using some rare items and/or their mechanics. Most of them will be simply eventually be obtained by players as they become familiar with the more common mechanics of the game and figure out playstyles that utilizes them or discover some of the less common mechanics of the game. 12 of the 46 Style Achievements have hidden descriptions that are only revealed after completing them. The borders of Style Achievement indicate their difficulty compared to other achievements with similar[[Comment]]TODO: Figure out a way to say "Achievements with almost exactly the same requirements, with the only difference being that one achievement requires doing thing A while the more difficult achievement requires doing thing A+B.", but use fewer words to say this.[[/Comment]] requirements, with more "intense" borders meaning higher difficulty.

Name: Terminal
Content:
Terminals are interactable Machines that [[Cogmind]] can hack for various benefits (such as recalling an [[Extermination Squad]]!) and info. Terminals are also often guarded by an [[Operator]], which if alerted will use this terminal to call for a [[Reinforcement Squad]] unless it or the terminal is disabled/destroyed.
The main differences between security levels and terminal types are are :
[[Table]]Security level|Average size|Armor|Direct hacks|Base direct hacking success rate|Base indirect hacking success rate|Base detection rate||
1|Small (1 tile and such)|18|Few available direct hacks|Depends on the hack|-15% compared to direct hacks|20 or 25%||
2|Medium|25|More available direct hacks|Half of level 1, rounded down|-30% compared to direct hacks|50%||
3|Large|30|Lots of available direct hacks|Half of level 2, rounded down|-45% compared to direct hacks|60%, 70% or 80%||
Terminals inside [[Garrison|Garrisons]]|Small (1 tile and such)|18|One of Access(Emergency), Download(Navigation), Download(Registry), or Download(Security)|Same as level 2|Same as level 2|Same as level 2||
Door-type/Lore terminals|Usually 1 tile|18|Usually one direct hack, to open the relevant door or get relevant lore record|Depends on door/lore record|Unavailable|Same as level 1||
Cave outpost terminal|1 tile|18|Random mix of flavor (useless) and intel "Report" hacks, with flavor reports always grouped on top of the list and intel reports grouped on the bottom of the list|100%|Unavailable|Same as level 1[[/Table]]
Non-door Garrion terminals are always security level 2, while door-type, lore, and cave outpost terminals are always level 1.

Unauthorized hacking (trojan and force hacks) success rate follows the same logic as direct hacking.

Download(Navigation), Download(Registry), and Download(Security) hacks are only available inside Garrisons.

The frequency of each Terminal security level is dependant on the area's depth. At depth -10, almost all terminals are level 1, a few are rarely level 2, and level 3 terminals are basically impossible to find[[Comment]]Maybe literally impossible?[[/Comment]]. As Cogmind ascends each depth, level 3 terminals become more common, while level 1 terminals become rarer. At first, level 2 terminals become more common, but eventually this reverses as they become less common. At depth -1, level 3 terminals are very common, level 2 terminals are rare while level 1 terminals are basically impossible to find[[Comment]]Maybe literally impossible?[[/Comment]] (excluding limited terminals).
[[Image]]../game_sprites/Terminal.png|Level 3 terminal![[/Image]]

[[Heading]]Hacking[[/Heading]]
Hacks are listed at [[~/hacks|the Cog-Minder Hacks page]], and explained further in the Cogmind manual.
Common chance factors:
[[List]]
Terminal Security Level - Higher-rated terminals are harder to hack, with direct hacks having half the base success rate they would have on a lower security terminal. Because of this, direct hacks with a negative base success rate will actually have a higher success rate on higher security terminals compared to lower security terminals (half of -8% is -4%).|
Manual Commands - (Security level * -15%) success chance penalty.|
[[Corruption]] - Penalty of -1% per 3% of system corruption to success chance.|
Use penalty - Successfully hacking Alert(Purge), Recall(Investigation), Recall(Reinforcements), Recall(Extermination) or Recall(Assault) permanently reduces the success rate for that specific hack by 10% for the entire map. This penalty is applied for every successful use of the relevant hack, lowering the success rate by 10% every time. The only way to remove it is to leave the map.
[[Hackware]] - Each attached offensive hackware improves success chances by the amount specified in the part description.|
Operator [[Data Core]] - Moving over an Operator's Data Core will automatically collect and it extract its dynamic key, which provides a one-time 1.5x multiplier to the base success rate of all direct hacks, excluding those with a negative base success rate. The dynamic key can only be used before it expires at its Operator's terminal.|
[[Multitool]] - Using a Multitool on a terminal's interactive tile removes all direct hacks and causes tracing to begin immediately, but applies a modifier to indirect hacks.|
[[Operator]] allies - Having allied Operators within 20 tiles provides a +10% bonus to hacks for the first Operator, +5% for the second, +2% for the third, and +1% for all others.|
[[Spoiler]]Botnets trojans - Installing Botnet trojans on other terminals in the same map provides a +6% bonus to hacks for the first botnet installed, +3% for the second, and +1% for all others. Note that a botnet will not affect hacking success chance on the terminal it is installed on.[[/Spoiler]]
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Detection/Trace[[/Heading]]
[[B]]Warning - This section is lacking in precision and information![[/B]] Please consider contributing to clarify it and/or add information.

Terminals have a varying base detection rate, dependent mostly on their security level. This base detection rate can be lowered through defensive hackware by the amount specified on their part description, and/or [[Spoiler]]permanently lowered by destroying Network Hubs in [[Hub_04(d)]][[/Spoiler]]. However, it can never be lowered below 10%.

Getting detected will cause a trace to start. Each additional hack attempt will cause the trace progress to advance by an amount which can be reduced in the same way as detection rate. Trace advance can never be lowered below 15%. When failing a hack, a catastrophic failure may occur (more likely on higher security terminals), causing the detection rate to go up by far more.

Getting fully traced may result in receiving [[Corruption]], your [[Hackware]] breaking, and will very likely cause an [[Investigation Squad]].

[[Heading]]Central database authorization[[/Heading]]
Indirect hacks for lore records, prototype IDs, part or robot schematics, and robot analyses, are all considered "database hacks". Successfully hacking any of them has a base 25% chance to instead cause an area-wide central database lockout, preventing further database hacks. However, direct hacks of those types remain possible after a central database lockout and cannot cause one.

Additionally, not all lore records, parts schematic, robot analyses or robot schematics can be indirectly hacked on all terminals. Terminals have a level of database authorization dependent on security level and current depth, equal to (10 - current depth + security level). It is only possible to indirectly hack a part/robot schematic or analysis if the terminal's authorization level is equal to or higher than the rating/tier of the relevant part/robot (prototype parts are considered to have a +1 to their rating for this purpose).
For example, at depth -5, level 2 terminals have an authorization level of (10 - 5 + 2) = 7.
Lore records also have a rating/tier, but it isn't communicated in-game. 

[[Heading]]Direct hacking subtleties[[/Heading]]
There are many small subtleties to direct hacking. Here is an incomplete list:
[[List]]
[[GameText]][Local Emergency Access][[/GameText]], [[GameText]][Purge Alert][[/GameText]] and all [[GameText]][Traps][[/GameText]] hacks appear greyed out in direct hacks if they are currently useless. In other words, if a terminal has a greyed out direct [[GameText]][Locate Traps][[/GameText]] hack, then there are no traps within the terminal's range.|
If either [[GameText]][Disarm Traps][[/GameText]] or [[GameText]][Reprogram Traps][[/GameText]] is available as a direct hack, then [[GameText]][Locate Traps][[/GameText]] will also be a direct hack on that terminal.|
If [[GameText]][Purge Alert][[/GameText]] is available as a direct hack, then [[GameText]][Check Alert][[/GameText]] will also be a direct hack on that terminal.|
If there is a direct [[GameText]][Recall][[/GameText]] hack available, then the corresponding [[GameText]][Status][[/GameText]] hack will also be available on that terminal.|
[[GameText]][Prototype ID Bank][[/GameText]] can only be hacked directly once, and is never greyed out, even when it does not yield new prototype IDs.|
When entering a map, if you already have a schematic that's supposed to appear on a terminal, that schematic hack may be re-rolled.[[Sup]][[Terminal#references|[1]]][[/Sup]]|
Direct [[GameText]][Schematic][[/GameText]] hacks may be of a higher rating/tier than the terminal's central database authorization, up to the same rating/tier as the current depth's level 3 terminals' central database authorization.
[[/List]]

Typical transport squads all start on the map, and more of them do not appear if destroyed. Transport squads can be Enumerated at [[Terminal|Terminals]], and a [[Transport Network Coupler]] or [[Modified TNC]] will reveal their current positions. The Modified TNC will also show the contents of all Haulers. Similarly, the Manifests hack shows all of the contents of all Haulers on the map, as well as any associated guards. Name: Warlord (Alignment)
Content:
Aligning with [[Warlord]] is one of the major faction [[Alignment|alignments]] available to Cogmind in a run and can be done in his [[Warlord (Location)|Base]] in either -5 or -4 [[Upper Caves]]. Aligning with Warlord has effects on 2 major events later in the game. It triggers an event where Warlord, [[God Mode]], and friendly [[Derelict|Derelicts]] assault -2 [[Research]]. It also has a lategame effect in [[Command]]: [[Redacted]]When opening the Command seals, [[Warlord (Command)]] will appear along with a group of other friendly Derelicts.[[/Redacted]]
One Warlord alignment-related item is the [[Encrypted Comm Array]]. If Cogmind either compromises [[Garrison|Garrison]] or [[Sterilization|sterilizes]] [[DSF|DSFs]], Cogmind can receive the Comm Array and learn the depth of Warlord's base. If enough assistance is provided, a force multiplier can provide allies during the -2 assault and in the [[Redacted]]Command Seals[[/Redacted]]. After seeing Warlord in his base, the Comm Array is no longer of any use.
[[Heading]]Restrictions[[/Heading]]
Cogmind cannot align with Warlord in the following scenarios:
[[List]][[RIF]] is installed - The base will be hostile to Cogmind upon entering the base|Attacking [[Scraptown]] - The base will be hostile to Cogmind upon entry|[[Imprint]] - Warlord will be disappointed in Cogmind|[[UFD]] - Warlord will think Cogmind is a spy[[/List]]
[[Heading]]-2 Research Assault[[/Heading]]
The event will begin with the alert [[GameText]]ALERT: Engineering response network critical failure, offline[[/GameText]]. More announcements will show up, but the next most important one will be [[GameText]]Warlord currently on norther/central/southern western approach. All units hit designated targets[[/GameText]] which indicates where Warlord and [[God Mode]] will appear on the map. 50 turns after entering the map, another announcement [[GameText]]Trap arrays successfully disabled[[/GameText]] will come with all traps being removed from the map. 110 after entering the maps, [[GameText]]Machine network successfully disabled[[/GameText]] will indicate that every machine on the map is now shut down except for [[Garrison (Machine)|Garrisons]] due to the follow-up message [[GameText]]Unrecognized interference restored Garrison access controls. Oops. Just blast them.[[/GameText]] 250 turns after entering the map and every 150 turns after that, 3 different assault squad spawns will appear from Garrisons and map exits with the message [[GameText]]Unaware assault squad dispatched in northeast/southeast/southwest/northwest quadrant.[[/GameText]] The spawn location will be indicated on the map. Every 100 turns 1 Derelict squad will spawn on the left side of the map for each tunnel. After 1000 turns on the map, Warlord will tell Cogmind that it is time to retreat and to open the [[Redacted]]Cave Seals in [[Command]] for the final push.[[/Redacted]]
[[Heading:2]]Downside of event[[/Heading]]
As a result of the Warlord assault, additional patrols will be dispatched in [[Testing]], [[Quarantine]], and [[Access]]. Patrols will increase by 40% in these maps. This is most significant in Access, upping the Patrol count from 20 to 28. A few Warlord bots will also appear at the entrance to these maps.
[[Image]]Research Warlord Squads.png|A few Derelict squads[[/Image]]
[[Heading]]Derelict Forces[[/Heading]]
The Derelict forces consist of many unique bots during this event. All of them appear as non-controllable allies that do not generate any alert for Cogmind. There are 3 spawn points in the form of giant tunnels. Each tunnel is dug out by a [[Borebot]] escorted by 2 [[Samaritan|Samaritans]]. They will dig straight across the map to the right side. Tiles that are dug out by Borebots are safe to travel on and will not cave-in. Warlord attack squads can vary greatly in composition but are made up of the following bots:
[[List]][[Butcher (7)|Butchers]]|[[Commander|Commanders]]|[[Dragon|Dragons]]|[[Fireman (7)|Firemen]]|[[Guerrilla (7)|Guerrillas]]|[[Hydra|Hydras]]|[[Knight]]|[[Marauder (8)|Marauders]]|[[Martyr (7)|Martyrs]]|[[Savage (7)|Savages]]|[[Thug (7)|Thugs]]|[[Troll|Trolls]]|[[Wasp (7)|Wasps]]|[[Wizard (7)|Wizards]][[/List]]
[[Image]]Research Warlord Assault Squads.png|0b10 Warlord response assault squad[[/Image]]The 0b10 forces come in groups of 3 bots. There are always 2 (not necessarily of the same type) of [[Executioner]], [[Striker]], and [[D-83 Annihilator]] bots along with a [[C-30 ARC|ARC]] full of bots. They roam around the map looking for bots to fight.
[[Heading:2]][[DD-05H]][[/Heading]]
Sometimes DD-05H will appear a few hundred turns into the invasion. It will run toward Warlord and then follow Warlord around for the duration of the event. When this happens, the [[Tinkerer]] PL-HR7 will also appear at one of the invasion entrances on the left side of the map. PL-HR7 will drop a [[Warlord Statue]] that Cogmind can use.
[[Heading]]Encrypted Comm Array[[/Heading]]
If Cogmind has aided Warlord forces by compromising Garrisons and DSFs, Cogmind may get 1 or 2 additional special escort squads based on the force multiplier. These special squads will head straight to Cogmind's location and follow. The higher the force multiplier, the stronger the squads available for escort. The special squads are as follows:
[[List]]Bridgeowners Association: Trolls|Cat Herders: Wasps|Death Star: Martyrs|Department No. 42: Firemen|Offensive Angels: Wasps|Golden Rifles: Commanders, Geurrillas, Surgeons, and Thugs|Grunt Murderers: Thugs|Gunslingers: Guerrillas|Lair Dwellers: Hydras|Lobotomizers: Wizards|Lucky Slug: Marauders|Magnificent Bastards: Mutants|Metalheads: Mutants|Knights of the Pentagonal Table: Knights|Railsplitters: Guerrillas|Shockpunchers: Wizards|Smaug Morners: Dragons|The Professionals: Commanders, Guerrillas, Knights, Surgeons, Trolls, and Wizards|Vikings: Butchers|Viscera Detail: Butchers and Savages[[/List]]
This event tends to be great for Cogmind. The primary downsides is that the machine network turns off relatively early into the event and locating the desired exit can be a pain. Getting stuck in a bad position without any Derelict allies can also be painful since the assaults, particularly the prototype bots and demolishers, pack quite a punch. However, the large number of alert-free allies and free loot from the bots fighting is great to any build. Like the Revision 17 event, this event will also cause the maps to have no Heavies. Finding any exit is usually possible by following the assault dispatch notifications. Assaults will be dispatched out of any Garrison or exit. The only exits that assaults do not come from are Quarantine prefab exits. In that case, using other infowar like terrain scanning and drones is the best way to locate these exits.

Name: Wins Achievements
Content:
Wins [[Achievements]] are earned by winning the game under certain conditions. 10 of the 37 Wins Achievements have hidden descriptions that are only revealed after completing them. The borders of Wins Achievements indicate whether they are earned by winning with a specific ending, winning under certain conditions, or winning while a challenge mode is active. The borders of Achievements for winning under certain conditions also indicate their difficulty compared to other achievements with similar requirements, with more "intense" borders meaning higher difficulty.

Name: Zhirov (Alignment)
Content:
[[Image]]Testing SGEMP.png|The SGEMP room in Testing[[/Image]]
Aligning with [[Zhirov]] is a minor [[Alignment|alignment]] that can be started in [[Zhirov (Location)|Zhirov's Lab]]. After entering and exiting the Terminal room on the left side of the map, Zhirov will ask Cogmind to steal the [[SGEMP Prototype]] from [[Testing]] and bring it to [[Access]]. If this is done, Zhirov, Perun, and Svarog will show up in Access and give Cogmind full map intel. They will follow Cogmind but will all teleport out if Zhirov falls below roughly half core integrity. They also leave if Cogmind enters [[Command]]. If a [[Core Reset Matrix]] is used prior to Access but Cogmind still carries the SGEMP, Zhirov and his allies will turn hostile and fight Cogmind to the death
There is a second part of this quest that continues in [[Command]]. [[Redacted]][[Image]]ModifiedSGEMP.gif|Zhirov detonating the modified SGEMP in Command, disabling MAIN.C[[/Image]]
After destroying the first form of [[MAIN.C (Shell)|MAIN.C]] in Command, Zhirov, Perun, and Svarog will show up and attack MAIN.C. Zhirov will activate the Modified SGEMP and disable all 0b10-aligned bots on the map. This also affects [[Warlord (Command)]], but no other Derelicts. This does stop Cogmind from getting the score bonuses of defeating [[MAIN.C]], as well as the + on the scoresheet.[[/Redacted]]
